description: Microsoft Technology Associate (MTA) is an introductory Microsoft certification for individuals considering a career in technology. The Windows Server Administration Fundamentals exam is designed to provide an assessment of knowledge of fundamental server administration concepts. It covers a wide range of topics, such as Windows Server, Windows-based networking, Active Directory, and system recovery. Upon completing the 98-365 exam, you will earn a Microsoft Technology Associate certification, which helps prove your knowledge of fundamental technology concepts. It can also serve as a stepping stone to the Microsoft Certified Technology Specialist exams.

subtitle: Windows Server Administration Fundamentals

00:25:22.320 --> 00:25:26.530
And I can see I'm now using,
if we can go over to that General tab.

519
00:25:26.530 --> 00:25:27.420
Or where can I see it?

520
00:25:27.420 --> 00:25:30.830
I can see the Microsoft USB wheel mouse.

521
00:25:30.830 --> 00:25:33.790
Optical, so I've updated that driver.

522
00:25:33.790 --> 00:25:35.935
Now, and
the reason I wanted to do that first,

523
00:25:35.935 --> 00:25:38.830
okay, one we need to know
how to update a driver.

524
00:25:38.830 --> 00:25:41.200
Two, I wanna talk about this next feature,

525
00:25:41.200 --> 00:25:44.470
the roll back driver feature
cuz this is an important one.

526
00:25:44.470 --> 00:25:49.250
Roll back driver gives me the ability
to go back to a previous driver.

527
00:25:49.250 --> 00:25:50.530
Hence the name rollback driver.

528
00:25:50.530 --> 00:25:53.670
It pretty much explains itself there.

529
00:25:53.670 --> 00:25:56.690
When you install a new driver,
hopefully you've done your research and

530
00:25:56.690 --> 00:25:59.020
you've found that this is
the driver that you need.

531
00:25:59.020 --> 00:25:59.660
Not always.

532
00:25:59.660 --> 00:26:01.360
Sometimes, that doesn't work.

533
00:26:01.360 --> 00:26:03.260
Maybe you got the wrong one accidentally.

534
00:26:03.260 --> 00:26:07.382
Maybe your user did this, and you're
just trying to pick up the pieces and

535
00:26:07.382 --> 00:26:09.191
get the machine working again.

536
00:26:09.191 --> 00:26:12.980
It's wonderful that Microsoft gives
us this feature, because what happens

537
00:26:12.980 --> 00:26:16.260
is that you update that driver,
and the new driver doesn't work.

538
00:26:16.260 --> 00:26:20.130
And now the device doesn't work, or
worse yet your screen locks up, or

539
00:26:20.130 --> 00:26:24.280
your blue screen, or something like that,
and now what do you do?

540
00:26:24.280 --> 00:26:27.500
Do you remember the driver that was
on there before that actually worked?

541
00:26:27.500 --> 00:26:29.230
Do you know what version it was?

542
00:26:29.230 --> 00:26:33.140
I don't remember what driver we put
there six months ago, a year ago,

543
00:26:33.140 --> 00:26:35.803
whatever how am I gonna
find that driver again?

544
00:26:35.803 --> 00:26:39.063
Well, I can simply choose
roll back driver and

545
00:26:39.063 --> 00:26:42.501
that will go back to
the previously used driver.

546
00:26:42.501 --> 00:26:46.480
Now, one notice the button wasn't
there before I had updated.

547
00:26:46.480 --> 00:26:51.200
If you've never updated the driver, then
there's nothing to roll back to, right?

548
00:26:51.200 --> 00:26:55.060
So if you've never updated it
that button will be grayed out.

549
00:26:55.060 --> 00:26:58.250
Two, it only remembers
the last used driver.

550
00:26:58.250 --> 00:27:00.650
It doesn't remember every
driver you've used.

551
00:27:00.650 --> 00:27:04.100
So if you've updated it from driver
A to driver B, and then from B to C,

552
00:27:04.100 --> 00:27:08.810
and then from C to D,
I can go back from D back to C.

553
00:27:08.810 --> 00:27:10.170
I can't go back to B or A, right?

554
00:27:10.170 --> 00:27:14.675
It only remembers the one previous driver,
but it's simple,

555
00:27:14.675 --> 00:27:17.148
I just say yes, and I click close.

556
00:27:17.148 --> 00:27:19.144
And it's gonna tell me I got to restart,

557
00:27:19.144 --> 00:27:21.862
or it should tell me I got to
restart to get back to that.

558
00:27:21.862 --> 00:27:23.661
I might have hidden that
button behind there.

559
00:27:23.661 --> 00:27:25.669
Let's see.

560
00:27:25.669 --> 00:27:26.761
Wow.

561
00:27:26.761 --> 00:27:29.187
This is actually not [CROSSTALK].

562
00:27:29.187 --> 00:27:32.043
Definitely does to get
that thing rolling again.

563
00:27:32.043 --> 00:27:34.946
Make sure I rolled it back.

564
00:27:34.946 --> 00:27:37.500
Maybe it doesn't.

565
00:27:37.500 --> 00:27:40.100
I've still got a warning
over here on my thing.

566
00:27:40.100 --> 00:27:46.225
Let's refresh this guy real quick,
and see what we've got here.

567
00:27:46.225 --> 00:27:50.318
[SOUND] Well,
let's just close device manager.

568
00:27:50.318 --> 00:27:52.950
It doesn't give me a nice
easy refresh option.

569
00:27:52.950 --> 00:27:57.740
We'll open that guy back up, and yeah,
it's still got a little warning on there,

570
00:27:57.740 --> 00:27:59.520
but that's okay.

571
00:27:59.520 --> 00:28:02.230
So anyway, I'm gonna go ahead and
restart it, just for giggles,

572
00:28:02.230 --> 00:28:04.600
cuz I understand,
even though Windows doesn't.

573
00:28:04.600 --> 00:28:06.650
I know to start using that new driver.

574
00:28:06.650 --> 00:28:10.216
It is gonna have to be restarted,
all right, but, so

575
00:28:10.216 --> 00:28:12.980
rollback driver is a great option.

576
00:28:12.980 --> 00:28:15.420
Even if, what if that machine,
what if it was a graphics driver and

577
00:28:15.420 --> 00:28:19.310
that machine had blue screen and
you couldn't log on because of it?

578
00:28:19.310 --> 00:28:21.240
Well, you can go into safe mode and

579
00:28:21.240 --> 00:28:25.420
then open up device manager from the
control panel and rollback that driver.

580
00:28:25.420 --> 00:28:27.559
So always keep that option in mind.

581
00:28:27.559 --> 00:28:31.379
If that doesn't work, or
if there's more than one driver, or for

582
00:28:31.379 --> 00:28:34.246
some reason that rollback
driver is not working,

583
00:28:34.246 --> 00:28:37.194
another option you could
do is the last known good.

584
00:28:37.194 --> 00:28:41.076
All right, when you reboot that server,
you can hit F8, pull up your boot menu,

585
00:28:41.076 --> 00:28:42.779
and you can choose last known good.

586
00:28:42.779 --> 00:28:47.323
And that's basically rolling your
registry back, which is gonna roll back

587
00:28:47.323 --> 00:28:52.020
the drivers that you were using the last
time the system successfully booted.

588
00:28:52.020 --> 00:28:53.971
All right.

589
00:28:53.971 --> 00:28:57.477
Sorry, let me log back in here.

590
00:28:57.477 --> 00:29:02.113
And we'll open up device
manager one more time,

591
00:29:02.113 --> 00:29:06.648
just to make sure I'm
back to the right driver.

592
00:29:06.648 --> 00:29:09.110
Okay, my system is giving me fits here.

593
00:29:09.110 --> 00:29:10.960
Didn't like it.

594
00:29:10.960 --> 00:29:12.750
And there we go, now my mice and

595
00:29:12.750 --> 00:29:17.090
pointing device is back to my good old
PS2 compatible mouse with no warning.

596
00:29:17.090 --> 00:29:18.390
So easy to do, right?

597
00:29:18.390 --> 00:29:20.420
We go into device manager,
you find the device,

598
00:29:20.420 --> 00:29:23.206
if you've gotta update a driver,
the button is there.

599
00:29:23.206 --> 00:29:26.560
If it's not an executable,
if it's an executable, you just run it and

600
00:29:26.560 --> 00:29:28.620
it's gonna go an update the driver for
you.

601
00:29:28.620 --> 00:29:30.900
If it's not an executable,
this is where you do it.

602
00:29:30.900 --> 00:29:34.650
Control panel, properties,
update driver button.

603
00:29:34.650 --> 00:29:38.005
If you've updated the driver and
that driver's causing you problems,

604
00:29:38.005 --> 00:29:40.322
then you can choose that
roll back driver button.

605
00:29:40.322 --> 00:29:45.496
Same place, control panel, device manager,
or you can do your boot options,

606
00:29:45.496 --> 00:29:49.761
F8 last known good, and
that will roll that driver back as well.

607
00:29:49.761 --> 00:29:52.754
Now the last thing I wanna go
over with this one Daniel,

608
00:29:52.754 --> 00:29:56.480
actually there's a few more things
we gotta go over aren't there?

609
00:29:56.480 --> 00:29:58.720
[CROSSTALK] Talking you
guys ear off out there.

610
00:29:58.720 --> 00:29:59.765
All right.

611
00:29:59.765 --> 00:30:02.470
Next thing I want to talk
about then is plug and play.

612
00:30:02.470 --> 00:30:06.077
Plug and play, PNP,
has been around since '98 I think?

613
00:30:06.077 --> 00:30:08.200
>> For awhile now, yeah.

614
00:30:08.200 --> 00:30:08.920
It's good stuff.

615
00:30:08.920 --> 00:30:09.750
That's why.

616
00:30:09.750 --> 00:30:11.345
>> It's a wonderful thing.

617
00:30:11.345 --> 00:30:15.283
Plug and play means when you plug that
device in, it's gonna automatically detect

618
00:30:15.283 --> 00:30:18.950
that there's a new piece of hardware and
it's gonna try to find that driver.

619
00:30:18.950 --> 00:30:22.230
And we should be familiar with
the steps that it goes through.

620
00:30:22.230 --> 00:30:24.049
The operating system's
gonna detect the change,

621
00:30:24.049 --> 00:30:26.010
it's gonna see that new piece of hardware.

622
00:30:26.010 --> 00:30:29.840
Now if it's a hot swappable, like a USB
thumb drive, or something like that,

623
00:30:29.840 --> 00:30:31.713
I didn't have to turn the system off.

624
00:30:31.713 --> 00:30:33.872
I just plug it in, it detects it.

625
00:30:33.872 --> 00:30:37.900
If it's not hot-swappable,
I power the machine down.

626
00:30:37.900 --> 00:30:39.370
I crack open the case.

627
00:30:39.370 --> 00:30:42.930
I throw in that new sound card, or
that video card, or that hard drive.

628
00:30:42.930 --> 00:30:45.060
I reboot the system, same thing happens.

629
00:30:45.060 --> 00:30:47.210
I log in, it detects that new hardware.

630
00:30:47.210 --> 00:30:49.380
So either way it's
detecting the new hardware.

631
00:30:49.380 --> 00:30:52.840
Whether it requires a reboot or
not, depends on the device.

632
00:30:52.840 --> 00:30:55.330
Then it's gonna query
the device itself for an ID.

633
00:30:55.330 --> 00:30:57.170
It says hey, what are you?

634
00:30:57.170 --> 00:31:01.230
And that device should report back, I'm
a video card right, or I'm a sound card.

635
00:31:01.230 --> 00:31:03.230
It'll give it that class ID.

636
00:31:03.230 --> 00:31:05.900
Then Windows is gonna go into
the driver store and look and

637
00:31:05.900 --> 00:31:08.960
see if it can find a driver
that matches that ID.

638
00:31:08.960 --> 00:31:13.080
And if it does,
it can grab that out of the driver store,

639
00:31:13.080 --> 00:31:17.570
install it where the operating system can
get to it, and then It will tell us we

640
00:31:17.570 --> 00:31:20.960
need to reboot our system for
those changes to take effect all right.

641
00:31:22.020 --> 00:31:24.015
If it doesn't find it
in the driver's store,

642
00:31:24.015 --> 00:31:28.490
PNP can actually go after Windows
update and find it there.

643
00:31:28.490 --> 00:31:30.540
If it doesn't find it
in any of those places.

644
00:31:30.540 --> 00:31:31.800
It's gonna prompt you.

645
00:31:31.800 --> 00:31:34.490
It's gonna say, hey, I don't know
where the drivers for this device.

646
00:31:34.490 --> 00:31:36.310
Do you have a disc that came with it?

647
00:31:36.310 --> 00:31:42.168
Give you the opportunity to put that disc
in there and upload or add that driver.

648
00:31:42.168 --> 00:31:46.271
And then Windows installs the driver,
configures it, or I'm sorry, PNP Util,

649
00:31:46.271 --> 00:31:50.433
the plug-and-play service installs that
driver and Windows configures it, and

650
00:31:50.433 --> 00:31:51.688
then you're good to go.

651
00:31:51.688 --> 00:31:54.094
>> It's always usually a good idea too,
and

652
00:31:54.094 --> 00:31:58.518
if it comes with a disk Install a disk
first, and then install the hardware.

653
00:31:58.518 --> 00:32:01.670
It'll find it immediately, and you don't
have to go through oh, do you have a disk?

654
00:32:01.670 --> 00:32:03.000
I couldn't find this.

655
00:32:03.000 --> 00:32:06.840
And kind of work it a little easier way,
anyway.

656
00:32:06.840 --> 00:32:10.937
>> And then the last thing on our list
of objectives that we gotta cover for

657
00:32:10.937 --> 00:32:12.678
drivers is the good old IRQs.

658
00:32:12.678 --> 00:32:15.394
And this is another one that,
honestly Daniel,

659
00:32:15.394 --> 00:32:17.592
when's the last you dealt with an IRQ.

660
00:32:17.592 --> 00:32:18.986
>> No.
Fifth and never.

661
00:32:18.986 --> 00:32:19.840
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, right.

662
00:32:19.840 --> 00:32:22.920
An IRQ is interrupt request.

663
00:32:22.920 --> 00:32:24.780
And when you have devices,

664
00:32:24.780 --> 00:32:27.620
they need to talk to the processor,
they can send a signal.

665
00:32:27.620 --> 00:32:31.890
I remember the way my old teacher years
ago taught me, it's like being on the bus.

666
00:32:31.890 --> 00:32:35.380
Your stop is coming up and you pull that
little cable, it rings that bell up there

667
00:32:35.380 --> 00:32:39.610
on the driver to get his attention and
say, hey, I need this bus to stop here.

668
00:32:39.610 --> 00:32:40.710
Same thing for these devices,

669
00:32:40.710 --> 00:32:44.350
lots of devices are talking to
the processor need processing time.

670
00:32:44.350 --> 00:32:46.960
They can send an interrupt
request to the processor, and

671
00:32:46.960 --> 00:32:49.620
it's just like sending
a signal to the bus driver.

672
00:32:49.620 --> 00:32:51.350
Hey processor, I need some time.

673
00:32:51.350 --> 00:32:54.340
Will you perform this
mathematical calculation for me,

674
00:32:54.340 --> 00:32:56.500
or whatever the case may be.

675
00:32:56.500 --> 00:33:00.470
And so our devices were assigned IRQs.

676
00:33:00.470 --> 00:33:04.096
IRQ was assigned to the device, and
that way when that device called at

677
00:33:04.096 --> 00:33:08.480
the processor, it knew what device
was asking for its attention.

678
00:33:08.480 --> 00:33:10.970
Well, they've really changed this process.

679
00:33:10.970 --> 00:33:14.180
It used to be a limited number
of IRQs you could assign.

680
00:33:14.180 --> 00:33:18.602
And, way back in the day, I remember
having conflicts because my sound card

681
00:33:18.602 --> 00:33:21.709
wanted to use the same IRQ
that my video card was for and

682
00:33:21.709 --> 00:33:23.319
I will tell you how old I am.

683
00:33:23.319 --> 00:33:27.551
There were dip switches on the sound
card that you would flip to change what

684
00:33:27.551 --> 00:33:29.542
IRQ is hard coated to use, right?

685
00:33:29.542 --> 00:33:32.966
Nowadays that's all done dynamically
through the operating system.

686
00:33:32.966 --> 00:33:37.641
There is virtual IRQs so we're not limited
to one through whatever at least if you

687
00:33:37.641 --> 00:33:39.440
want 15 I think originally.

688
00:33:40.640 --> 00:33:45.000
Now we've got an unlimited number
because they're basically virtualized.

689
00:33:45.000 --> 00:33:49.740
I can't think of any reason why how
you're ever gonna run into a situation

690
00:33:49.740 --> 00:33:51.110
where you need to worry about that, but

691
00:33:51.110 --> 00:33:54.480
for the exam we should talk about it and
know what it is.

692
00:33:54.480 --> 00:33:56.640
So let's take a look at
my screen here again.

693
00:33:56.640 --> 00:33:58.375
And I'm going to look at, I don't know.

694
00:33:58.375 --> 00:34:00.320
I'll look at my display adapter here.

695
00:34:00.320 --> 00:34:02.170
And I'm just going to go
over the resources tab.

696
00:34:02.170 --> 00:34:04.140
And here you can see a few things.

697
00:34:04.140 --> 00:34:07.170
One of which, I'll see if I got my IO.

698
00:34:07.170 --> 00:34:08.340
I got my input output.

699
00:34:08.340 --> 00:34:10.820
That one actually doesn't have an IRQ.

700
00:34:10.820 --> 00:34:13.450
Go back to my mouse cuz
I know he's got one.

701
00:34:14.960 --> 00:34:16.660
And there's an example of an IRQ.

702
00:34:16.660 --> 00:34:20.650
So he's got IRQ number 12
that's been assigned to him.

703
00:34:20.650 --> 00:34:24.930
Again, I don't think there's any reason I
would ever need to change any of these.

704
00:34:24.930 --> 00:34:30.220
But if you need to know what the IRQ
address is or IDs for that device.

705
00:34:30.220 --> 00:34:34.210
You can come in here and you can see that,
dynamically handled by Windows.

706
00:34:34.210 --> 00:34:35.600
We really don't mess with them anymore.

707
00:34:35.600 --> 00:34:39.277
>> Yeah, thank you so much Windows for
[LAUGH] handling that for us cuz, I mean,

708
00:34:39.277 --> 00:34:43.086
IRQs and when I was learning all this
stuff, that was the bane of my existence.

709
00:34:43.086 --> 00:34:47.690
I hated trying to have to memorize
exactly what IRQ went with what device.

710
00:34:47.690 --> 00:34:49.220
It was so confusing to me.

711
00:34:49.220 --> 00:34:53.470
So the fact that it's all dynamically
assigned now, oh, the heavens have opened.

712
00:34:53.470 --> 00:34:54.595
>> Yes.
>> And it is a glorious day.

713
00:34:54.595 --> 00:34:56.350
>> [LAUGH]
>> So thank goodness.

714
00:34:56.350 --> 00:34:57.040
All right, Mike.

715
00:34:57.040 --> 00:35:00.030
Have we got anything else we need to
talk about when it comes to these

716
00:35:00.030 --> 00:35:00.760
device drivers?

717
00:35:00.760 --> 00:35:02.280
>> For
drivers I think we've covered it all.

718
00:35:02.280 --> 00:35:05.630
The main thing to remember is that you've
got to get the driver for the device.

719
00:35:05.630 --> 00:35:08.910
Windows has a few built-in but
go to the manufacturer's website.

720
00:35:08.910 --> 00:35:11.861
Get the appropriate one, 32-bit or 64-bit.

721
00:35:11.861 --> 00:35:15.279
Make sure you're an administrator
to install it or

722
00:35:15.279 --> 00:35:19.260
have it pre-loaded into that
driver store using PNP Util.

723
00:35:19.260 --> 00:35:23.729
If you ever have a problem with a drive
that you've installed, you can rollback

724
00:35:23.729 --> 00:35:28.148
to the previous by using that rollback
driver button there in device manager.

725
00:35:28.148 --> 00:35:29.530
And I think those are the big points.

726
00:35:29.530 --> 00:35:30.120
>> Yep.

727
00:35:30.120 --> 00:35:30.820
All right.

728
00:35:30.820 --> 00:35:33.090
Well everybody out there,
hopefully you've got all that down, and

729
00:35:33.090 --> 00:35:35.190
you are now device driver savvy.

730
00:35:35.190 --> 00:35:37.230
That being said,
we're gonna go ahead and call it a day.

731
00:35:37.230 --> 00:35:40.730
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

732
00:35:40.730 --> 00:35:41.493
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

733
00:35:41.493 --> 00:35:42.839
>> And we'll see you next time.

734
00:35:42.839 --> 00:35:49.470

So this is my WDS server,
my deployment server,

572
00:28:57.220 --> 00:29:01.120
and what we're gonna do is we're gonna
create what we call a reference machine.

573
00:29:01.120 --> 00:29:05.115
And that's simply a machine that
I've installed 2008 R2 on, and

574
00:29:05.115 --> 00:29:07.525
I've done some basic configuration to it.

575
00:29:07.525 --> 00:29:11.995
I've got the operating system installed,
maybe given it a generic name.

576
00:29:11.995 --> 00:29:16.370
If there's any applications, maybe,
that I wanna include on that.

577
00:29:16.370 --> 00:29:20.060
That all my servers are gonna need,
whatever I want to do.

578
00:29:20.060 --> 00:29:23.230
Then we're going to CIS prep it,

579
00:29:23.230 --> 00:29:26.740
which is a way that I can remove any
uniquely identifying information.

580
00:29:26.740 --> 00:29:29.040
Basically generify?

581
00:29:29.040 --> 00:29:29.955
Is that a word?

582
00:29:29.955 --> 00:29:32.510
>> [LAUGHS]
>> We're gonna generalize the OS which

583
00:29:32.510 --> 00:29:35.330
means strip out any unique GUI,

584
00:29:35.330 --> 00:29:40.110
numbers, that identify this machine,
right, make it very neutral.

585
00:29:40.110 --> 00:29:43.140
And then we're gonna copy,
we're gonna take a picture

586
00:29:43.140 --> 00:29:46.820
of that machine's hard drive, we're
gonna create an image of that machine,

587
00:29:46.820 --> 00:29:51.540
and we're gonna load that image
over here on my deployment server.

588
00:29:51.540 --> 00:29:56.170
Once I've got that image of that reference
machine loaded up on my deployment server,

589
00:29:56.170 --> 00:30:00.530
I can simply go to a machine on my
network, connect it across the network to

590
00:30:00.530 --> 00:30:05.760
the deployment sever, pick that image,
and deploy it out to this machine.

591
00:30:05.760 --> 00:30:08.070
And then, I can walk over to the next
do one and do the same thing.

592
00:30:08.070 --> 00:30:10.360
And walk over to the next one and
do the same thing.

593
00:30:10.360 --> 00:30:13.020
And within the time that I
just installed one server, but

594
00:30:13.020 --> 00:30:17.230
here on this show, I could have
multiple servers installed, right.

595
00:30:17.230 --> 00:30:20.440
So, you're just basically creating
an image of that hard drive, and

596
00:30:20.440 --> 00:30:23.550
then you're applying
that image to these guys.

597
00:30:23.550 --> 00:30:28.002
And as soon as one of these guys boots up,
it will replace all that information that

598
00:30:28.002 --> 00:30:32.214
got stripped out before I created it,
that it will be unique to this machine.

599
00:30:32.214 --> 00:30:36.470
This guy will create his own GUI,
this guy will create his own GUI, right.

600
00:30:36.470 --> 00:30:41.288
So in a big environment, in an enterprise
environment, when you're responsible for

601
00:30:41.288 --> 00:30:45.974
deploying many servers, or you need to be
able to roll out new servers very quickly,

602
00:30:45.974 --> 00:30:48.090
Deployment Services is the way to go.

603
00:30:48.090 --> 00:30:49.680
And this is free.

604
00:30:49.680 --> 00:30:51.400
This is a role that I can install.

605
00:30:51.400 --> 00:30:55.590
If I have a Server 2008 R2 machine
on my network, I can install

606
00:30:55.590 --> 00:30:59.620
Deployment Services, and I can set all
this up without any additional cost.

607
00:30:59.620 --> 00:31:04.000
I mean I need the licensing,
right, to go on these guys here.

608
00:31:04.000 --> 00:31:06.250
But as far as this goes, it's great.

609
00:31:06.250 --> 00:31:10.845
This guy doesn't even need an operating
system, I can boot him up to the network

610
00:31:10.845 --> 00:31:15.180
adapter using something called PXE boot,
Pre Executable Environment.

611
00:31:15.180 --> 00:31:17.480
I can connect him to
that Deployment Server.

612
00:31:17.480 --> 00:31:22.430
If I have multiple, I might have several
images stored up on a Deployment Server.

613
00:31:22.430 --> 00:31:26.340
Here's an image of a Server
2008 R2 DHCP server.

614
00:31:26.340 --> 00:31:29.580
Here's an image of a 2008 R2 DNS server.

615
00:31:29.580 --> 00:31:32.880
When I go to connect this guy across
the network to my Deployment Server,

616
00:31:32.880 --> 00:31:34.160
I can pick from a list.

617
00:31:34.160 --> 00:31:37.390
Which image do I wanna
deploy out to this machine?

618
00:31:37.390 --> 00:31:39.770
Fantastic, I love Deployment Services.

619
00:31:39.770 --> 00:31:42.360
And this guy's finished already.

620
00:31:42.360 --> 00:31:44.006
All I gotta do is set up the password.

621
00:31:47.006 --> 00:31:50.720
And I get to log in and there we go.

622
00:31:50.720 --> 00:31:55.040
I now have a brand new 2008
R2 server sitting here.

623
00:31:55.040 --> 00:31:55.910
>> That's very awesome.

624
00:31:55.910 --> 00:32:01.040
As we saw, it's very, very simple, it
doesn't take a lot of crazy configuration.

625
00:32:01.040 --> 00:32:04.170
You don't need to be some
computer genius to get

626
00:32:04.170 --> 00:32:06.060
Server 2008 R2 installed on a machine.

627
00:32:06.060 --> 00:32:07.850
It's very, very simple.

628
00:32:07.850 --> 00:32:12.070
You pop your disc in, walk through
the questionnaire that they give you,

629
00:32:12.070 --> 00:32:13.240
do a little partitioning.

630
00:32:13.240 --> 00:32:14.250
Nothing to it.

631
00:32:14.250 --> 00:32:18.500
And within just 15 minutes maybe
you should be up and running.

632
00:32:18.500 --> 00:32:21.940
I do love that unattended answer file that
does make our lives a whole lot easier.

633
00:32:21.940 --> 00:32:22.480
>> It sure does.

634
00:32:22.480 --> 00:32:25.530
>> All right Mikey, is there anything else
we need to discuss to these good people

635
00:32:25.530 --> 00:32:27.200
about this installation?

636
00:32:27.200 --> 00:32:32.080
>> I will mention that with the Deployment
Services, because you make that image

637
00:32:32.080 --> 00:32:34.990
generic, you run it through,
you generalize it, and then put it up on

638
00:32:34.990 --> 00:32:38.800
the deployment server, and then push
it out to as many servers as you need.

639
00:32:38.800 --> 00:32:41.720
When they start up for the first time,
they've got to generate that information

640
00:32:41.720 --> 00:32:45.710
that got stripped out and they're going
to go through that initial set up wizard.

641
00:32:45.710 --> 00:32:47.680
You can automate that as well.

642
00:32:47.680 --> 00:32:51.490
You can create an answer file for
WDS deployment, and so

643
00:32:51.490 --> 00:32:53.830
I don't even have to just sit there and
wait for those guys to finish.

644
00:32:53.830 --> 00:32:56.950
I can have an answer file, and
completely automate that process as well.

645
00:32:56.950 --> 00:32:59.175
>> Huge fan of automation,
I love it, love it.

646
00:32:59.175 --> 00:33:00.030
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right,

647
00:33:00.030 --> 00:33:04.080
well hopefully you guys have gotten a good
taste of what is involved when you install

648
00:33:04.080 --> 00:33:06.670
the server software itself and
how to get that done.

649
00:33:06.670 --> 00:33:09.710
We're going to go ahead and sign off,
and thank you for watching.

650
00:33:09.710 --> 00:33:10.980
I've been your host, Daniel Lowery.

651
00:33:10.980 --> 00:33:11.960
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

652
00:33:11.960 --> 00:33:14.340
>> And we'll see you next time.

653
00:33:14.340 --> 00:33:15.100
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue exploring Server 20082 installation fundamentals; kicking things off with F8 boot options. Then they describe the differences and similarities between Windows Server 2008R2 Core vs. Full versions. Also covered are best practices concerning BIOS and Firmware updates.
episodes.title: Server Install Options Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.822 --> 00:00:16.269
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.269 --> 00:00:20.391
I'm your host Daniel Lowry, here with me
today is none other than Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:20.391 --> 00:00:21.420
How's it going today Mikey?

5
00:00:21.420 --> 00:00:22.576
>> Oh, it's going great Daniel.

6
00:00:22.576 --> 00:00:27.315
I am excited because we've got more of our
MTA Windows server fundamentals coming

7
00:00:27.315 --> 00:00:27.940
your way.

8
00:00:27.940 --> 00:00:31.102
Windows server administration
fundamentals, nice long title for

9
00:00:31.102 --> 00:00:31.605
that one.

10
00:00:31.605 --> 00:00:35.620
And we're actually continuing on
with our installation options.

11
00:00:35.620 --> 00:00:37.815
So we got a few more things
that we weren't able to squeeze

12
00:00:37.815 --> 00:00:39.030
into that previous episode.

13
00:00:39.030 --> 00:00:41.546
If you missed it,
make sure you go back and watch it.

14
00:00:41.546 --> 00:00:43.670
We're continuing on here.

15
00:00:43.670 --> 00:00:48.675
And Daniel, the next thing to call out
on our objectives is the F8 options.

16
00:00:48.675 --> 00:00:51.688
>> It's a good question right there, Mike.

17
00:00:51.688 --> 00:00:54.807
You notice he didn't ask a question,
but I said, that's a good question?

18
00:00:54.807 --> 00:00:58.656
That's because it's very odd to us that
this would be part of the installation

19
00:00:58.656 --> 00:00:59.560
options.

20
00:00:59.560 --> 00:01:03.400
Normally this is something that you
would do for troubleshooting, but

21
00:01:03.400 --> 00:01:06.450
they put it here so we're gonna
call it out here for you as well.

22
00:01:06.450 --> 00:01:09.750
F8 options Mike, like I said,
normally used for troubleshooting.

23
00:01:09.750 --> 00:01:12.790
Can you think of any reason that we
might use them for installation?

24
00:01:12.790 --> 00:01:15.165
>> I don't even think they're
available before the install but

25
00:01:15.165 --> 00:01:16.863
I mean maybe I'm wrong, never tried that.

26
00:01:16.863 --> 00:01:18.821
But, I don't think they are.

27
00:01:18.821 --> 00:01:23.308
But regardless, it's gonna be on the exam,
or it could be a question on the exam so

28
00:01:23.308 --> 00:01:25.073
we're gonna cover it, right.

29
00:01:25.073 --> 00:01:27.638
Where maybe they just couldn't
figure out where else to put it, and

30
00:01:27.638 --> 00:01:28.859
this is where it ended up going.

31
00:01:28.859 --> 00:01:31.980
So F8, you might have done this
on your own machine at home.

32
00:01:31.980 --> 00:01:34.220
It's also available in server.

33
00:01:34.220 --> 00:01:38.766
It how we get into our advanced boot
options, is basically what it is.

34
00:01:38.766 --> 00:01:40.492
I'm gonna try to do it
here on this server.

35
00:01:40.492 --> 00:01:45.084
We are virtualizing these machines and
sometimes in a virtual environment,

36
00:01:45.084 --> 00:01:48.343
it can be really tricky because
they boot so darn fast.

37
00:01:48.343 --> 00:01:49.655
But, I'll go ahead and show you here.

38
00:01:49.655 --> 00:01:54.326
So, basically, what you would do is, you
would reboot your server and during that

39
00:01:54.326 --> 00:01:58.466
reboot, during that post process
before the operating system kicks in,

40
00:01:58.466 --> 00:02:01.289
you're going to be hitting
F8 on your keyboard.

41
00:02:01.289 --> 00:02:04.230
And that should bring you to
your advanced boot options.

42
00:02:04.230 --> 00:02:08.980
It means I don't want Windows to
boot normally because, most likely,

43
00:02:08.980 --> 00:02:10.810
something is going wrong.

44
00:02:10.810 --> 00:02:11.720
So let's try it here.

45
00:02:11.720 --> 00:02:14.860
I'm gonna go ahead and restart this guy.

46
00:02:14.860 --> 00:02:18.010
I'll just go to my Start menu and
choose Restart.

47
00:02:18.010 --> 00:02:21.162
And I'll give it a reason,
a very descriptive reason there.

48
00:02:21.162 --> 00:02:22.088
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

49
00:02:22.088 --> 00:02:25.350
I'm getting my finger ready
on the F8 button right now.

50
00:02:25.350 --> 00:02:29.165
So as soon as that thing starts going
black, I'm hitting F8, and we'll see.

51
00:02:29.165 --> 00:02:32.950
Now if you see the Windows bar load up
like that, that means you missed it.

52
00:02:32.950 --> 00:02:37.046
And you must wait for Windows to finish
booting, and then you can try it again.

53
00:02:37.046 --> 00:02:40.140
>> Now, Mike, I'm sure you did that for
purely demonstration purposes.

54
00:02:40.140 --> 00:02:41.580
Not that it was just too quick for you.

55
00:02:41.580 --> 00:02:42.370
>> [LAUGH] Exactly yes.

56
00:02:42.370 --> 00:02:46.137
>> Even if they're the speed of a mongoose
and the reflexes of a cat I'm sure.

57
00:02:46.137 --> 00:02:47.377
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah exactly,

58
00:02:47.377 --> 00:02:52.052
that's what I'm gonna say, that's my
story now and I'm sticking to it, right?

59
00:02:52.052 --> 00:02:56.112
So here we go and fortunately on server
you can't restart it from the log on

60
00:02:56.112 --> 00:02:59.190
screen otherwise somebody
could walk by your server and

61
00:02:59.190 --> 00:03:02.350
just hit the client down at
the bottom right hand corner.

62
00:03:02.350 --> 00:03:06.409
You can restart it right from
the log on screen on server, not so.

63
00:03:06.409 --> 00:03:08.543
I don't want anybody to
be able to walk by and

64
00:03:08.543 --> 00:03:10.690
reboot my server without authenticating.

65
00:03:10.690 --> 00:03:13.977
So I know who it is that
decided to reboot my server.

66
00:03:13.977 --> 00:03:15.290
So we'll try this one more time.

67
00:03:15.290 --> 00:03:19.317
I'll go over here and
I'll choose Restart and

68
00:03:19.317 --> 00:03:23.870
again I'll get my fingers
ready on that F8 button.

69
00:03:23.870 --> 00:03:27.770
Who knows, maybe I pushed F7 by mistake
I might've fat fingered that guy.

70
00:03:27.770 --> 00:03:29.210
I'm pushing it up there we go.

71
00:03:29.210 --> 00:03:31.645
I will tell you what I do personally.

72
00:03:31.645 --> 00:03:34.740
As soon as that screen goes black,
I just start tapping it.

73
00:03:34.740 --> 00:03:38.559
You don't wanna do it like [SOUND] cuz
then you'll actually get a keyboard

74
00:03:38.559 --> 00:03:39.445
failure error.

75
00:03:39.445 --> 00:03:42.578
But you do wanna go tap,
tap, tap, tap, tap, tap,

76
00:03:42.578 --> 00:03:47.120
until it either gives you the Windows
logon screen or you come to this.

77
00:03:47.120 --> 00:03:48.750
And this is what we were shooting for,
so here we go.

78
00:03:48.750 --> 00:03:52.420
Here's our advanced boot options for
server 2008 R2.

79
00:03:52.420 --> 00:03:55.340
I can launch into repair mode.

80
00:03:55.340 --> 00:03:58.680
This would allow me try to
repair the installation.

81
00:03:58.680 --> 00:04:04.059
Maybe that's why this falls under
server installation as a possibility.

82
00:04:04.059 --> 00:04:05.960
You basically start this.

83
00:04:05.960 --> 00:04:08.332
You would hit, if I choose restart.

84
00:04:08.332 --> 00:04:09.686
I should've gone through
the rest of the menu.

85
00:04:09.686 --> 00:04:12.980
Now I'm going to have to
hit that thing again.

86
00:04:12.980 --> 00:04:14.242
But this is gonna bring you,

87
00:04:14.242 --> 00:04:17.302
it's gonna look like it's installing
the operating system again.

88
00:04:17.302 --> 00:04:20.130
And it does freak some
people out sometimes.

89
00:04:20.130 --> 00:04:22.710
They panic, they go hey,
I didn't want to reinstall.

90
00:04:22.710 --> 00:04:24.635
And there was nothing,
I just wanted to fix,

91
00:04:24.635 --> 00:04:26.470
I was having trouble booting the machine.

92
00:04:26.470 --> 00:04:29.330
I got some start up files
that need to be replaced.

93
00:04:29.330 --> 00:04:33.300
Don't worry, it's not actually gonna
reinstall the operating system.

94
00:04:33.300 --> 00:04:34.700
Here's my recovery options.

95
00:04:34.700 --> 00:04:39.621
I can click next on that, and
I would authenticate with my local admin,

96
00:04:39.621 --> 00:04:41.353
username and password.

97
00:04:41.353 --> 00:04:44.530
And here I can get into
my System Image Recovery.

98
00:04:44.530 --> 00:04:48.090
So if I had a system image that
I had created ahead of time,

99
00:04:48.090 --> 00:04:50.220
right, I could try to restore that.

100
00:04:50.220 --> 00:04:53.100
I can also launch my
Windows Memory Diagnostics, or

101
00:04:53.100 --> 00:04:54.939
I could go into a Command Prompt.

102
00:04:54.939 --> 00:04:58.565
And maybe I've got some command
line utilities that I wanna try

103
00:04:58.565 --> 00:05:00.010
to run to fix the system.

104
00:05:00.010 --> 00:05:03.759
Like, I don't know,
maybe I'm doing some scan disk, or

105
00:05:03.759 --> 00:05:07.058
some other type of commands
that I might try to run.

106
00:05:07.058 --> 00:05:10.734
I'm just gonna go ahead and choose restart
cuz there's nothing wrong with this, and

107
00:05:10.734 --> 00:05:14.060
I wanna show you the rest of
the options on that advanced boot menu.

108
00:05:14.060 --> 00:05:17.066
So we're gonna try it one more time,
let's see how my reflexes are.

109
00:05:17.066 --> 00:05:21.199
What you do is restart,
I'll do my F8 and there we go.

110
00:05:21.199 --> 00:05:22.481
All right, Safe Mode.

111
00:05:22.481 --> 00:05:23.988
There's a whole bunch of options here,

112
00:05:23.988 --> 00:05:27.050
there's really a few of them that
you need to be familiar with.

113
00:05:27.050 --> 00:05:29.813
Safe Mode is one of them, right?

114
00:05:29.813 --> 00:05:31.510
Safe Mode is an important one.

115
00:05:31.510 --> 00:05:34.640
Typically if my system
won't boot properly,

116
00:05:34.640 --> 00:05:38.560
in other words, I start up this server and
it goes into a boot loop.

117
00:05:38.560 --> 00:05:43.812
Or it boots up and it blue screens, and
then it restarts and it blue screens.

118
00:05:43.812 --> 00:05:45.350
How do I fix that system?

119
00:05:45.350 --> 00:05:47.010
I need to get it up and running so

120
00:05:47.010 --> 00:05:50.590
I can try to get in there and fix it,
Safe Mode is what I'm gonna use.

121
00:05:50.590 --> 00:05:57.440
Safe Mode basically loads only known
good drivers from the driver store.

122
00:05:57.440 --> 00:06:01.506
Usually when we have a blue screen or
something, a good majority of the time,

123
00:06:01.506 --> 00:06:03.509
is because I've done something bad,

124
00:06:03.509 --> 00:06:08.130
I've installed a driver that's not
compatible and it's causing a problem.

125
00:06:08.130 --> 00:06:11.942
Safe Mode, but there's other reasons
that you can end up blue screening,

126
00:06:11.942 --> 00:06:18.120
Safe Mode allows me to get into that
system by just loading known good drivers.

127
00:06:18.120 --> 00:06:22.720
And let's take a peek at Safe Mode,
it does look a little bit different.

128
00:06:22.720 --> 00:06:25.114
You can see all the drivers
that it's loading up,

129
00:06:25.114 --> 00:06:27.002
none of your custom drivers will load.

130
00:06:27.002 --> 00:06:33.490
Like if you had any video drivers,
soundcard drivers or anything like that.

131
00:06:33.490 --> 00:06:35.920
And so, it's a good troubleshooting tip.

132
00:06:35.920 --> 00:06:40.702
If I can't boot the system normally,
but I can boot the system in Safe Mode,

133
00:06:40.702 --> 00:06:45.338
there's a good bet that the problem
lies with something in the registry of

134
00:06:45.338 --> 00:06:46.708
the driver, right?

135
00:06:46.708 --> 00:06:48.370
And here's good old Safe Mode.

136
00:06:48.370 --> 00:06:53.656
You can see it's very low resolution,
800 by 600, something like that.

137
00:06:53.656 --> 00:06:56.910
It's got Safe Mode in
the corner of all these guys,

138
00:06:56.910 --> 00:06:59.440
letting me know that I'm in Safe Mode.

139
00:06:59.440 --> 00:07:04.220
But, now I can at least function, and I
can try to go do a driver rollback, right.

140
00:07:04.220 --> 00:07:08.961
We've seen that in another episode where
now I can get into device manager, and

141
00:07:08.961 --> 00:07:13.023
I could go roll back a driver that

00:05:42.670 --> 00:05:44.910

00:06:38.650 --> 00:06:42.920

00:06:42.920 --> 00:06:49.220

the user's gonna have to

00:06:49.220 --> 00:06:53.790

136
00:06:53.790 --> 00:06:58.280
If my admin told me that, hey,
it's on a different URL, or

137
00:06:58.280 --> 00:07:02.040

I could come over here and

138
00:07:02.040 --> 00:07:08.360

139
00:07:08.360 --> 00:07:12.710
then 88 for example, a different port
number, connect to a non default port.

140
00:07:12.710 --> 00:07:16.340
Now that port on my server is not open
because I'm using the default port, but

141
00:07:16.340 --> 00:07:19.620
that's what you would do is you could
specify a different port number

142
00:07:19.620 --> 00:07:22.230
if you were, again,
hosting multiple web sites.

143
00:07:23.540 --> 00:07:24.820
All right?

144
00:07:24.820 --> 00:07:29.000
HTTP is plain text, meaning that all
the data that's being sent back and

145
00:07:29.000 --> 00:07:33.230
forth between you and
that web server is not encrypted.

146
00:07:33.230 --> 00:07:34.260
It's not protected.

147
00:07:34.260 --> 00:07:39.390
So anybody in between you could intercept
that information and read that.

148
00:07:39.390 --> 00:07:40.920
And, well who's in between you?

149
00:07:40.920 --> 00:07:44.348
Well, if you're connecting to Newegg,
or to your bank, or what have you,

150
00:07:44.348 --> 00:07:47.671
anybody on the internet could potentially,
right, be in between you and

151
00:07:47.671 --> 00:07:50.962
that server because you're going
across that public infrastructure.

152
00:07:50.962 --> 00:07:54.109
And that's where HTTPS comes into play.

153
00:07:54.109 --> 00:08:02.930
HTTPS is my Using SSL, it's called Secure
Socket Layer or TLS is a newer form.

154
00:08:02.930 --> 00:08:05.820
But for this example I think
we'll just stick with SSL.

155
00:08:05.820 --> 00:08:07.510
You put that S on the end of it and

156
00:08:07.510 --> 00:08:10.250
it changes the port number
you're connecting to.

157
00:08:10.250 --> 00:08:15.500
And now you're gonna be going over port
443 by default again that can be changed

158
00:08:15.500 --> 00:08:18.110
and that's the port we
attempt to connect to.

159
00:08:18.110 --> 00:08:21.260
But it has to be set up on

160
00:08:21.260 --> 00:08:25.853
Like we'll this site that I
just made again is using HTTP,

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explain the file and print services found in the Windows Server operating system. Here they show you how to connect both local and network printers and then move into more complex options like printer pools and web printing and management. Also covered is driver deployment, auditing and print job management.
episodes.title: File and Print Services

568
00:30:03.500 --> 00:30:06.400
I take them out of the group,
and I'm done, right?

569
00:30:06.400 --> 00:30:09.372
So, in a small organization,
sometimes it's hard

570
00:30:09.372 --> 00:30:13.558
to see the benefit of following this
strategy, but as your system grows,

571
00:30:13.558 --> 00:30:18.375
as your corporation grows, you'll be very
glad you followed this basic strategy.

572
00:30:18.375 --> 00:30:22.596
AGDLP, accounts into global group,
global groups into domain local groups,

573
00:30:22.596 --> 00:30:25.890
permissions get assigned
at the domain local groups.

574
00:30:25.890 --> 00:30:29.970
Now, as you're studying for this,
if you start reading anything beyond 2008,

575
00:30:29.970 --> 00:30:35.220
you're gonna see that Microsoft
changed it up a little bit.

576
00:30:35.220 --> 00:30:41.580
There gonna call it IGDLA, just to
confuse us, because why keep it the same?

577
00:30:41.580 --> 00:30:42.840
Let's change it.

578
00:30:42.840 --> 00:30:45.460
It's the exact same strategy, all right?

579
00:30:45.460 --> 00:30:51.550
Except accounts are now called identities
and permission is now called access.

580
00:30:51.550 --> 00:30:55.770
So identities go in to global groups
global groups in domain local groups,

581
00:30:55.770 --> 00:30:58.610
domain local groups are given
access to the resource.

582
00:30:58.610 --> 00:31:01.425
IGDLA, it's the same thing as AGDLP,

583
00:31:01.425 --> 00:31:06.218
just a little different twist on
the actual terms there at the end.

584
00:31:06.218 --> 00:31:09.670
>> For this exam, AGDLP will get you by.

585
00:31:09.670 --> 00:31:10.990
That's what you want to learn.

586
00:31:10.990 --> 00:31:13.700
So stick with that, and
then once you move beyond this, and

587
00:31:13.700 --> 00:31:17.390
you maybe move into higher certifications,
then you can start worrying about

588
00:31:17.390 --> 00:31:20.620
how they've changed a little bit
differently for newer exams.

589
00:31:20.620 --> 00:31:24.580
All right Mike, well we've covered a lot
of users and groups with Active Directory.

590
00:31:24.580 --> 00:31:27.230
Is there anything else we need to
add to this or are we good to go?

591
00:31:27.230 --> 00:31:28.443
>> I think that's it.

592
00:31:28.443 --> 00:31:31.616
If I'm gonna give you any parting words,
go in there and

593
00:31:31.616 --> 00:31:34.800
play if you've got a virtual
environment to play with.

594
00:31:34.800 --> 00:31:36.290
Try signing permissions.

595
00:31:36.290 --> 00:31:38.310
Try creating some of those groups.

596
00:31:38.310 --> 00:31:39.360
Look at your different options.

597
00:31:39.360 --> 00:31:40.650
Put some accounts in there.

598
00:31:40.650 --> 00:31:41.330
Create some folders.

599
00:31:41.330 --> 00:31:42.430
Assign supervisions.

600
00:31:42.430 --> 00:31:46.000
Play around with it and
get used to to the way those work.

601
00:31:46.000 --> 00:31:47.150
Try roaming profiles too.

602
00:31:47.150 --> 00:31:47.810
>> That's right.

603
00:31:47.810 --> 00:31:49.250
I second that motion.

604
00:31:49.250 --> 00:31:51.782
Most of them pass, all in favor say, aye.

605
00:31:51.782 --> 00:31:54.490
All right Michael, looks like we've come
to the right of yet another great episode.

606
00:31:54.490 --> 00:31:58.381
Hopefully you guys have enjoyed it, we're
gonna go ahead and sign off for ITProTV.

607
00:31:58.381 --> 00:32:00.020
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

608
00:32:00.020 --> 00:32:00.790
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

609
00:32:00.790 --> 00:32:02.655
>> And we'll see you next time.

610
00:32:02.655 --> 00:32:08.440
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel explain Organizational Units and Containers found in Microsoft's Active Directory. They walk you through the purpose, plan, and practical implementation of OUs as well as showing you how to create custom OUs for your own purposes. Also covered is how to use OUs to delegate authority.
episodes.title: OUs and Containers
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.688 --> 00:00:13.523
All right, greetings everyone.

3
00:00:13.523 --> 00:00:16.540
Welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:16.540 --> 00:00:20.476
I'm your host Daniel Lowery,
here with me today is Mr. Mike Roderick.

5
00:00:20.476 --> 00:00:21.550
How's it going today Michael?

6
00:00:21.550 --> 00:00:22.730
>> It's going great Daniel.

7
00:00:22.730 --> 00:00:25.500
I'm excited because we've
got more of our MTA,

8
00:00:25.500 --> 00:00:29.710
Windows Server administration
fundamentals coming your way and

9
00:00:29.710 --> 00:00:34.310
in this one we're gonna be
looking at OU's and containers.

10
00:00:34.310 --> 00:00:36.980
OUs being organizational units.

11
00:00:36.980 --> 00:00:39.960
Sorry, I hate using acronyms
before I define them, but

12
00:00:39.960 --> 00:00:41.325
that's the title of the objective.

13
00:00:41.325 --> 00:00:42.844
O-Using containers [LAUGH].

14
00:00:42.844 --> 00:00:46.610
>> Yeah, we tend to get a little used
to using the Microsoft terminology.

15
00:00:46.610 --> 00:00:50.590
Once you've been acclimated
to Microsoft's way, as it is,

16
00:00:50.590 --> 00:00:54.540
you'll be spitting out terminology left
and right, acronyms left and right.

17
00:00:54.540 --> 00:00:55.160
Michael is right.

18
00:00:55.160 --> 00:00:57.280
Right now we need to give you the meat and
potatoes of it.

19
00:00:57.280 --> 00:00:59.580
OU is organizational unit.

20
00:00:59.580 --> 00:01:03.670
And it's a hinky little thing inside
of the Active Directory, eh, Mike?

21
00:01:03.670 --> 00:01:05.975
>> Yeah!
>> It's weird and ambiguous and yet,

22
00:01:05.975 --> 00:01:07.889
defined all at the same time [LAUGH].

23
00:01:07.889 --> 00:01:08.830
>> It's so wonderful.

24
00:01:08.830 --> 00:01:12.180
You will learn to love OUs, and honestly
if you're new to Active Directory and

25
00:01:12.180 --> 00:01:14.059
you're trying to figure these things out,

26
00:01:14.059 --> 00:01:16.550
well, one,
what I'm gonna explain them to you.

27
00:01:16.550 --> 00:01:21.510
And two, you're gonna find that there's a
lot of similarities to folders, all right?

28
00:01:21.510 --> 00:01:26.800
Between an OU and so
if you take that concept of folders, cuz

29
00:01:26.800 --> 00:01:31.030
most of you are used to creating folders
then subfolders most likely, right?

30
00:01:31.030 --> 00:01:33.520
Like you've got your My Pictures
folder on your computer.

31
00:01:33.520 --> 00:01:36.740
You don't dump all of your pictures
into that folder most likely.

32
00:01:36.740 --> 00:01:42.271
You make subfolders within there,
Christmas, 2015, New Year's 2016.

33
00:01:42.271 --> 00:01:44.923
You make different subfolders,
and that makes it easier for

34
00:01:44.923 --> 00:01:47.940
you to find a picture when
you're looking for it, right?

35
00:01:47.940 --> 00:01:51.690
Well, the same thing in Active Directory
when we look at organizational units,

36
00:01:51.690 --> 00:01:56.800
the name kind of implies,
we're organizing things using these units.

37
00:01:56.800 --> 00:02:00.465
And they are in that respect,
some very similar folders.

38
00:02:00.465 --> 00:02:03.560
Now they go well beyond
what we use folders for,

39
00:02:03.560 --> 00:02:05.380
lot of cool things we can do with OU's.

40
00:02:05.380 --> 00:02:08.363
So let's dive in, I'm gonna go
jump over here to my computer.

41
00:02:08.363 --> 00:02:12.069
We're going to open up Active Directory
and we're gonna take a look

42
00:02:12.069 --> 00:02:15.330
at what these OUs look like and
talk a little bit about them.

43
00:02:15.330 --> 00:02:18.770
So I am going to jump over
to the domain controller

44
00:02:18.770 --> 00:02:20.980
because that's where I would
find Active Directory.

45
00:02:20.980 --> 00:02:26.270
[LAUGH] And I'm going to launch
Active Directory, users and computers.

46
00:02:26.270 --> 00:02:28.750
Funny how its not on my web server Daniel?

47
00:02:28.750 --> 00:02:30.940
>> It's amazing how that works
out isn't it, Micheal [LAUGH]?

48
00:02:30.940 --> 00:02:32.366
>> [LAUGH] It is.
All right, so here we are,

49
00:02:32.366 --> 00:02:35.770
all the domain controller, I've launched
Active Directory users and computers.

50
00:02:35.770 --> 00:02:37.680
I'm gonna kind of
collapse this up just for

51
00:02:37.680 --> 00:02:40.130
a second so
we can start from the very beginning.

52
00:02:40.130 --> 00:02:43.480
Now when you open up Active Directory,
you've got your domain.

53
00:02:43.480 --> 00:02:47.370
In this case, my domain is named lab.net.

54
00:02:47.370 --> 00:02:51.540
And underneath here,
I've got what looks like folders.

55
00:02:51.540 --> 00:02:53.750
And there's a couple of different ones.

56
00:02:53.750 --> 00:02:58.270
I know it's probably really hard for
you to see on my screen here.

57
00:02:58.270 --> 00:03:01.980
So, make sure you fire up
a domain controller, or

58
00:03:01.980 --> 00:03:05.920
go look at our practice labs, or
whatever, to get a little closer look.

59
00:03:05.920 --> 00:03:10.870
But the folders here, the little icons,
some of them look like plain

60
00:03:10.870 --> 00:03:15.620
yellow folders, the other ones have
a little, what's supposed to be a book, or

61
00:03:15.620 --> 00:03:18.350
I've always thought it kind of
looked like a little scroll.

62
00:03:18.350 --> 00:03:21.000
It's really hard to see, and
I've never bothered trying to

63
00:03:21.000 --> 00:03:23.390
break out a magnifying glass and
take a close look at it.

64
00:03:23.390 --> 00:03:26.370
But, that is a key distinction here when

65
00:03:26.370 --> 00:03:28.370
we're looking in Active Directory,
all right?

66
00:03:28.370 --> 00:03:32.760
The ones with the little book or
scroll icon on them,

67
00:03:32.760 --> 00:03:37.370
those our organizational units,
or OUs for short.

68
00:03:37.370 --> 00:03:43.190
The other ones, the little plain yellow
ones there, those are known as containers.

69
00:03:43.190 --> 00:03:45.760
Now here's where it gets a little twisty,
so pay attention.

70
00:03:47.290 --> 00:03:49.810
OU's are a type of container, right?

71
00:03:49.810 --> 00:03:52.990
So, really they're both containers,
but the yellow ones,

72
00:03:52.990 --> 00:03:57.090
the ones with out the little icon,
those are known as built in containers.

73
00:03:57.090 --> 00:04:01.087
The OU's are a special class of
containers that I can create and

74
00:04:01.087 --> 00:04:05.848
they have more functionality than
those built in containers, all right?

75
00:04:05.848 --> 00:04:07.610
And that's the last that
I'll confuse you with that.

76
00:04:07.610 --> 00:04:10.060
We're gonna stick with containers and OUs.

77
00:04:10.060 --> 00:04:11.520
But just for the exam and for

78
00:04:11.520 --> 00:04:15.430
your information,
know that an OU is also a container.

79
00:04:15.430 --> 00:04:18.100
It's just a special class of container,
all right?

80
00:04:18.100 --> 00:04:21.540
And when I say it's a container,
that's because it contains objects, right?

81
00:04:21.540 --> 00:04:26.360
Just like folders that you create in your
file explorer on your desktop, right?

82
00:04:27.430 --> 00:04:28.730
Those can contain objects,

83
00:04:28.730 --> 00:04:33.900
you can put things inside them, files,
other folders, pictures, things like that.

84
00:04:33.900 --> 00:04:35.360
These are containers as well and

85
00:04:35.360 --> 00:04:38.980
when I go into these guys,
I'll find things inside them.

86
00:04:38.980 --> 00:04:44.260
Just like I would if I was navigating
through my file system on my computer.

87
00:04:44.260 --> 00:04:48.280
So for example, here's the built
in container called BuiltIn.

88
00:04:48.280 --> 00:04:50.040
There's some more confusion for you.

89
00:04:50.040 --> 00:04:54.532
It's a built in container called BuiltIn,
yeah well.

90
00:04:54.532 --> 00:04:55.660
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's Microsoft.

91
00:04:55.660 --> 00:04:57.148
There's a Computers container.

92
00:04:57.148 --> 00:04:58.960
Now some of these you don't normally see.

93
00:04:58.960 --> 00:05:01.080
Let me change this back
to the default view.

94
00:05:01.080 --> 00:05:03.450
I'm gonna turn off my advanced features.

95
00:05:03.450 --> 00:05:05.508
This is what you'd normally
see when you come in here.

96
00:05:05.508 --> 00:05:09.900
You'll see that my list got shorter,
right?

97
00:05:09.900 --> 00:05:12.680
Some of those containers,
I don't see by default.

98
00:05:12.680 --> 00:05:17.400
If I want to see them, I've gotta
turn on that Advanced view, right?

99
00:05:17.400 --> 00:05:21.570
Also, when you're looking at these guys,
if I right-click on one and

100
00:05:21.570 --> 00:05:25.310
pull up Properties,
I don't see the security tab, right?

101
00:05:25.310 --> 00:05:28.583
I don't see that until I
turn on my advanced view.

102
00:05:28.583 --> 00:05:29.780
I go to my View menu.

103
00:05:29.780 --> 00:05:34.100
Turn on Advanced features and
now you see my list here gets longer.

104
00:05:34.100 --> 00:05:36.850
And as well when I right-click
on one of these guys and

105
00:05:36.850 --> 00:05:39.840
choose Properties I now
get a few extra tabs.

106
00:05:39.840 --> 00:05:41.510
One of them being that Security tab.

107
00:05:41.510 --> 00:05:44.270
Though not specifically called
out in the objectives but

108
00:05:44.270 --> 00:05:46.130
something I wanted to let you guys know.

109
00:05:46.130 --> 00:05:48.730
You're not seeing everything when
you go into Active Directory

110
00:05:48.730 --> 00:05:51.440
until you turn on that
Advanced features view.

111
00:05:52.840 --> 00:05:56.030
All right, so let's go back through here,
and I'm gonna make it a little bit easier

112
00:05:56.030 --> 00:05:59.630
to look at just by turning off
that Advanced features for now.

113
00:05:59.630 --> 00:06:02.700
So BuiltIn, these yellow one's again,
BuiltIn containers.

114
00:06:02.700 --> 00:06:04.140
There's one called BuiltIn.

115
00:06:04.140 --> 00:06:07.470
And this has a bunch of
groups in it already.

116
00:06:07.470 --> 00:06:10.230
This was all created when I
installed Active Directory.

117
00:06:10.230 --> 00:06:13.710
I didn't make any of this,
as far as the containers go and

118
00:06:13.710 --> 00:06:15.380
what's contained in them.

119
00:06:15.380 --> 00:06:18.250
Hence the name BuiltIn containers, right?

120
00:06:18.250 --> 00:06:21.290
That came with Active Directory,
the computers container.

121
00:06:22.420 --> 00:06:25.990
This is actually left over
from the NT days, all right?

122
00:06:25.990 --> 00:06:30.012
And this is the default location for
a new computer account.

123
00:06:30.012 --> 00:06:33.825
In other words, when I get that
new Windows 7 box in, and I go and

124
00:06:33.825 --> 00:06:37.075
I join it to the domain,
I'm gonna find the account for

125
00:06:37.075 --> 00:06:40.483
that computer here in
the computers container, right?

126
00:06:40.483 --> 00:06:42.210
That's what it's for.

127
00:06:42.210 --> 00:06:46.430
There's a Foreign Security Principals
container, a Manage Security Accounts or

128
00:06:46.430 --> 00:06:49.220
Service Accounts container,
and a Users container.

129
00:06:49.220 --> 00:06:53.960
And the Users container contains
additional groups as well as a couple key

130
00:06:53.960 --> 00:06:56.952
accounts, Administrator and Guest, okay?

131
00:06:56.952 --> 00:06:58.552
Now all that stuff that
I just talked about,

132
00:06:58.552 --> 00:07:01.440
that all comes with an Active Directory,
I didn't create any of that.

133
00:07:01.440 --> 00:07:03.918
That's what we call our default creators.

134
00:07:03.918 --> 00:07:07.900
Again, that BuiltIn there,

135
00:07:07.900 --> 00:07:13.300
this is for service administrator
accounts, so you'll see things like IIS,

136
00:07:13.300 --> 00:07:18.570
I users, performance log users
print operators, server operators.

137
00:07:18.570 --> 00:07:21.380
What we call our service
administrator account.

138
00:07:21.380 --> 00:07:23.670
And that's where they're
located by default.

139
00:07:23.670 --> 00:07:24.780
Now I can move them.

140
00:07:24.780 --> 00:07:29.260
Microsoft says we probably should just
leave them in there, and that's fine.

141
00:07:29.260 --> 00:07:33.643
That said, the Computer's container
is the default location for

142
00:07:33.643 --> 00:07:36.624
new computer objects and Active Directory.

143
00:07:36.624 --> 00:07:40.624
Foreign Security Principles, honestly
I'll tell you that I've never really used

144
00:07:40.624 --> 00:07:43.399
this container in the 12 years
that I've been doing it.

145
00:07:43.399 --> 00:07:46.020
Manage Service Accounts,

146
00:07:46.020 --> 00:07:51.180
we've talked about in other episodes how
we can create a manage service account.

147
00:07:51.180 --> 00:07:52.707
That's where they would show up.

148
00:07:52.707 --> 00:07:55.140
And then this default Users container.

149
00:07:55.140 --> 00:07:57.582
This is where new user
accounts are gonna go.

150
00:07:57.582 --> 00:08:01.089
Just like new computers go
in the Computers container,

151
00:08:01.089 --> 00:08:03.740
new users go in the Users container.

152
00:08:03.740 --> 00:08:05.744
Again, by default, right?

153
00:08:05.744 --> 00:08:10.580
What I'm trying to get you to get
there is that I can change that.

154
00:08:10.580 --> 00:08:12.750
I don't have to stick with the default.

155
00:08:12.750 --> 00:08:14.530
Right, but those containers,

156
00:08:14.530 --> 00:08:18.780
as I said a minute ago, when I install
active directory, it creates those,

157
00:08:18.780 --> 00:08:24.180
it populates them with
all of those options.

158
00:08:24.180 --> 00:08:27.580
There's only one OU that we
get by default out of the box

159
00:08:27.580 --> 00:08:29.430
when we first install Active Directory.

160
00:08:29.430 --> 00:08:32.179
And that is the Domain Controllers OU.

161
00:08:32.179 --> 00:08:35.660
It is an organizational unit, you can
see the icon is slightly different.

162
00:08:35.660 --> 00:08:39.668
And this is the default location for
the computer accounts for

163
00:08:39.668 --> 00:08:41.850
my domain controllers.

164
00:08:41.850 --> 00:08:43.900
All the others are gonna
go into Computers.

165
00:08:43.900 --> 00:08:44.800
Domain controllers,

166
00:08:44.800 --> 00:08:50.220
a special computer on my network,
they go into the Domain Controllers OU.

167
00:08:50.220 --> 00:08:52.250
And so that's what I get by default.

168
00:08:52.250 --> 00:08:54.630
Everything else,
I get to create on my own.

169
00:08:54.630 --> 00:08:57.450
Like I've got an OU here
called Client Computers.

170
00:08:57.450 --> 00:09:01.410
And inside there,
I've got GNV and NYC, right.

171
00:09:01.410 --> 00:09:03.480
I created those, those weren't there.

172
00:09:03.480 --> 00:09:06.920
I've got an Employee's container,
I mean OU, sorry.

173
00:09:06.920 --> 00:09:09.820
And inside there I've got Groups,
and Hosts, and Managers,

174
00:09:09.820 --> 00:09:11.740
and Operations, right?

175
00:09:11.740 --> 00:09:16.470
And we create these OUs for
a couple of different reasons.

176
00:09:16.470 --> 00:09:19.440
First and foremost is just to
organize by objects, right?

177
00:09:19.440 --> 00:09:22.350
Because if I'm looking for
Daniel's account, well,

178
00:09:22.350 --> 00:09:25.480
I know Daniel's an employee here and
he's a host.

179
00:09:25.480 --> 00:09:28.984
So I could expand out Employees,
go down to Hosts.

180
00:09:28.984 --> 00:09:31.420
And it's chugging along.

181
00:09:31.420 --> 00:09:34.730
But sure enough, there's the account for
Daniel, all right.

182
00:09:34.730 --> 00:09:39.386
So just organizing my objects
is the first reason we use OUs.

183
00:09:39.386 --> 00:09:43.527
Now, Microsoft actually doesn't put
that as part of their uses for OUs.

184
00:09:43.527 --> 00:09:46.412
I'll tell you,

00:27:09.289 --> 00:27:12.320
gets generated for every object
we create in Active Directory.

517
00:27:12.320 --> 00:27:15.360
Well, every security principal
in Active Directory.

518
00:27:15.360 --> 00:27:19.470
If more than one person was
generating those unique numbers,

519
00:27:19.470 --> 00:27:21.150
we'd have a chance for duplication.

520
00:27:21.150 --> 00:27:24.310
So there's one person responsible for
generating those numbers and

521
00:27:24.310 --> 00:27:26.383
that is your RID Master.

522
00:27:26.383 --> 00:27:29.215
Now that domain-wide rules mean just that,
right.

523
00:27:29.215 --> 00:27:33.930
Forest-wide meant one per forest,
domain-wide means means one per domain.

524
00:27:33.930 --> 00:27:38.064
So this second domain down here,
it has its own PDC emulator for

525
00:27:38.064 --> 00:27:43.681
time synchronization, and PDC emulation,
and browser lists and things like that.

526
00:27:43.681 --> 00:27:47.760
Has its own infrastructure master for
checking references to foreign objects.

527
00:27:47.760 --> 00:27:51.980
Has its own RID Master for
generating those relative identifiers.

528
00:27:51.980 --> 00:27:54.830
This domain over here,
has its own PDC emulator,

529
00:27:54.830 --> 00:27:57.730
infrastructure master and RID Master.

530
00:27:57.730 --> 00:28:00.130
But notice they don't
have a schema master or

531
00:28:00.130 --> 00:28:05.270
a Domain Naming Master,
because those two are forest-wide, right.

532
00:28:05.270 --> 00:28:08.110
And that's probably good for
now, there's a ton more.

533
00:28:08.110 --> 00:28:11.552
I mean I could talk about FSMOs for
probably another hour or two.

534
00:28:11.552 --> 00:28:12.320
>> [LAUGH].

535
00:28:12.320 --> 00:28:16.944
>> But since Daniel's eyes were glazing
over, it means yours probably are too, so

536
00:28:16.944 --> 00:28:18.584
we'll stop there, right.

537
00:28:18.584 --> 00:28:23.017
[LAUGH] All right, so we've talked about
domain controllers, we've talked about

538
00:28:23.017 --> 00:28:27.670
forest, we're talked about domains,
we've talked about operation masters.

539
00:28:27.670 --> 00:28:31.890
What else, we talked about contiguous
namespaces and child domains.

540
00:28:34.020 --> 00:28:35.110
We talked about namespaces,

541
00:28:35.110 --> 00:28:40.360
we need to talk about sites,
trusts and functional levels here.

542
00:28:40.360 --> 00:28:44.520
Sites, well,
let's go back to replication for a second.

543
00:28:44.520 --> 00:28:47.010
When we talk about replication, right,

544
00:28:47.010 --> 00:28:51.170
that's how changes propagate from
one domain controller to another.

545
00:28:51.170 --> 00:28:53.337
If I make a change on
domain controller one,

546
00:28:53.337 --> 00:28:56.333
that change is gonna replicate
over domain controller two.

547
00:28:56.333 --> 00:28:58.580
Let's say I create a new user account,
right?

548
00:28:58.580 --> 00:29:01.750
Well, when you log on,
if I've got two domain controllers,

549
00:29:01.750 --> 00:29:05.030
I don't know which domain controller
your talking to when you go to log on.

550
00:29:05.030 --> 00:29:08.260
If I make your user account
on domain controller one,

551
00:29:08.260 --> 00:29:10.280
what if you talked to
domain controller two?

552
00:29:10.280 --> 00:29:13.830
He needs to know about your user account
as well, so that's what replication does.

553
00:29:13.830 --> 00:29:17.050
It replicates the data to
the different domain controllers.

554
00:29:17.050 --> 00:29:21.390
And within a domain,
replication occurs quickly, all right.

555
00:29:21.390 --> 00:29:25.960
It's really within, oh gosh,
let me think about it,

556
00:29:25.960 --> 00:29:29.220
it's no more than three hops,
it's within five minutes.

557
00:29:29.220 --> 00:29:31.196
No, is that right?

558
00:29:31.196 --> 00:29:32.356
Yeah, five ten minutes,

559
00:29:32.356 --> 00:29:35.570
that change will be replicated
throughout your entire domain.

560
00:29:35.570 --> 00:29:37.740
It does not take long at all,

561
00:29:37.740 --> 00:29:40.440
because as soon I make a change
on one domain controller.

562
00:29:40.440 --> 00:29:42.930
He's gonna notify his
replication partners say hey,

563
00:29:42.930 --> 00:29:45.650
I've got a change that
these will be replicating.

564
00:29:45.650 --> 00:29:49.555
He's gonna call right back and say, let's
go ahead and replicate, all right, and

565
00:29:49.555 --> 00:29:50.490
he'll replicate.

566
00:29:50.490 --> 00:29:54.460
And then he's gonna send it to his
replication partner, and so on and

567
00:29:54.460 --> 00:29:55.480
so forth.

568
00:29:55.480 --> 00:29:58.720
And so it replicates very quickly.

569
00:29:58.720 --> 00:30:03.590
Well, we won't go into
the three hop rule just yet,

570
00:30:03.590 --> 00:30:05.040
we'll save that for another show.

571
00:30:06.080 --> 00:30:08.960
Sometimes though I don't
need that process to happen.

572
00:30:08.960 --> 00:30:12.440
In other words, I've got domain
controllers here in Gainesville.

573
00:30:12.440 --> 00:30:15.930
I've got another office in Pensacola and
I've got domain controllers there.

574
00:30:15.930 --> 00:30:17.900
All part of the same domain, right?

575
00:30:17.900 --> 00:30:21.220
But I've got an office here, and
I've got an office out in Pensacola.

576
00:30:21.220 --> 00:30:24.980
So when I make a change here, I got two or
three domain controllers here and

577
00:30:24.980 --> 00:30:27.120
it replicates very quickly and
that's great.

578
00:30:28.290 --> 00:30:30.950
But what about replicating
it over to Pensacola?

579
00:30:30.950 --> 00:30:32.960
Now I'm going across this WAN link.

580
00:30:32.960 --> 00:30:34.753
And that WAN link might be slow and

581
00:30:34.753 --> 00:30:38.034
I've got users trying to access
resources on the Internet.

582
00:30:38.034 --> 00:30:41.710
I don't need Active Directory replication
sucking up all the bandwidth.

583
00:30:41.710 --> 00:30:45.458
Replicating every single change
immediately right over to Pensacola,

584
00:30:45.458 --> 00:30:46.000
right?

585
00:30:46.000 --> 00:30:49.160
So we create what we call sites.

586
00:30:49.160 --> 00:30:55.665
Sites within Active Directory are way
to really define physical boundaries.

587
00:30:55.665 --> 00:30:59.310
Cuz a domain is logical,
I can have an office here and in Tokyo,

588
00:30:59.310 --> 00:31:01.037
and it can all be part of the same domain,
right?

589
00:31:02.330 --> 00:31:06.410
But my physical separation,
how do I define that in Active Directory?

590
00:31:06.410 --> 00:31:09.720
We create sites, I have a GNV site.

591
00:31:09.720 --> 00:31:14.970
I have a Pensacola or
New York City site, all right.

592
00:31:14.970 --> 00:31:16.940
And why do I do this?

593
00:31:16.940 --> 00:31:21.780
Because within a site,
replication occurs almost immediately.

594
00:31:21.780 --> 00:31:25.410
Between sites,
I can control when it happens.

595
00:31:25.410 --> 00:31:27.270
By default it's every three hours.

596
00:31:27.270 --> 00:31:31.050
I can slow that down, I can speed
it up but it's under my control.

597
00:31:31.050 --> 00:31:34.020
So if I have limited bandwidth
between Gainesville and New York.

598
00:31:34.020 --> 00:31:38.050
I can say look, don't replicate in five
minutes, let's give it an hour, right.

599
00:31:38.050 --> 00:31:42.250
If I'm making a new user account here,
the user's logging on here most likely,

600
00:31:42.250 --> 00:31:46.350
I don't need that change to get up
to New York immediately, right?

601
00:31:46.350 --> 00:31:52.170
So sites for now, what I want you to
think about sites is a way to define my

602
00:31:52.170 --> 00:31:59.900
areas of my network that have high
speed reliable connectivity, all right.

603
00:31:59.900 --> 00:32:04.800
The other thing that sites do for me,
is they allow me to localize services.

604
00:32:06.160 --> 00:32:09.920
As I said earlier, domain controllers
have all the same information,

605
00:32:09.920 --> 00:32:11.470
they all replicate with each other.

606
00:32:11.470 --> 00:32:14.520
So if I'm sitting here in the Gainesville
office and I go to log on,

607
00:32:14.520 --> 00:32:17.325
I could talk to to either one of these
domain controllers in Gainesville.

608
00:32:17.325 --> 00:32:19.815
I could also talk to either one of
these domain controllers in New York.

609
00:32:19.815 --> 00:32:22.665
They all know about my user account.

610
00:32:22.665 --> 00:32:25.605
But if I'm in Gainesville, wouldn't it
make more sense to talk to the domain

611
00:32:25.605 --> 00:32:28.690
controller that's right here on
the same high speed network as me?

612
00:32:28.690 --> 00:32:33.010
Why wait for my log on traffic to make
all the way to New York and come back.

613
00:32:33.010 --> 00:32:36.130
When I've got a domain controller
on the network right next to me,

614
00:32:36.130 --> 00:32:37.855
sites allow me to do that.

615
00:32:37.855 --> 00:32:38.980
Those sites allow me to say,

616
00:32:38.980 --> 00:32:43.680
when you log on log on with a domain
controller in the same site as you.

617
00:32:43.680 --> 00:32:46.120
There's other services and things
that can take advantage of this, but

618
00:32:46.120 --> 00:32:48.010
I know I'm getting the evil eye.

619
00:32:48.010 --> 00:32:53.866
We're running out of time and for
this exam, the main thing is we understand

620
00:32:53.866 --> 00:32:59.173
that sites are just a way to define
the portions of my network that have

621
00:32:59.173 --> 00:33:04.740
high speed, reliable connectivity and
to localize services.

622
00:33:04.740 --> 00:33:07.232
And that I think Daniel,
did I get through most of it?

623
00:33:07.232 --> 00:33:09.149
>> I think you got through
everything my friend.

00:33:09.149 --> 00:33:10.760
>> That was a lot of information, right?

00:33:10.760 --> 00:33:14.620
>> It is definitely a lot of information,
but it shows you how important it is

00:33:14.620 --> 00:33:17.530
to understand the Active Directory
infrastructure.

627
00:33:17.530 --> 00:33:21.720
It's not a small thing, it is a very
large thing as a matter of fact.

628
00:33:21.720 --> 00:33:23.750
There's a lot of detail
that goes along with it.

629
00:33:23.750 --> 00:33:29.910
But the more you master that detail,
the better you'll do at controlling

630
00:33:29.910 --> 00:33:33.390
the Active Directory infrastructure,
the better set up it will be.

631
00:33:33.390 --> 00:33:35.040
All right Mikey,
you did a great job though.

632
00:33:35.040 --> 00:33:35.900
We thank you so much for

633
00:33:35.900 --> 00:33:40.100
those demonstrations, those explanations
of the Active Directory infrastructure.

634
00:33:40.100 --> 00:33:41.950
I guess we're gonna go ahead and
call it a day.

635
00:33:41.950 --> 00:33:45.550
Signing off for ITProTV,

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike discuss Group Policy for controlling a Windows Active Directory environment. They start by explaining the how, when, and where Group Policy is applied to computers and/or users; then they show you how to create Group Policy Objects (GPO) in your own domain or local computer.

you go to create a user specific policy.

559
00:28:55.460 --> 00:28:57.240
And this is the processing order.

560
00:28:57.240 --> 00:29:02.650
So if we think back to my processing
order here, local, site, domain, OU.

561
00:29:02.650 --> 00:29:07.310
If we said local was first, one, and then
site was two, and then domain was third,

562
00:29:07.310 --> 00:29:12.460
and then OU was fourth, well now we've
got to kind of look at it like well local

563
00:29:12.460 --> 00:29:17.630
policy is one, administrator or
non-administrator is like one A, user

564
00:29:17.630 --> 00:29:23.330
specific might be one B, and then back
to site, and then domain, and then OU.

565
00:29:23.330 --> 00:29:24.300
Right?

566
00:29:24.300 --> 00:29:29.070
So, it's really local, and then
administrators and non-administrators, and

567
00:29:29.070 --> 00:29:34.300
then users specific if there is one, and
then site, and then domain, and then OU.

568
00:29:34.300 --> 00:29:36.875
But the acronym doesn't work out
nearly as well when you do all that.

569
00:29:36.875 --> 00:29:38.592
>> [LAUGH]
>> So you just called it LSDO, and

570
00:29:38.592 --> 00:29:41.157
then we threw all this over here to say,
oh by the way,

571
00:29:41.157 --> 00:29:44.220
you have more than one local
policy that you have to deal with.

572
00:29:44.220 --> 00:29:45.960
And important that we
understand that order as well,

573
00:29:45.960 --> 00:29:50.210
because if we change the order,
we change the outcome of the policy.

574
00:29:50.210 --> 00:29:51.950
Right, remember what I was showing you.

575
00:29:51.950 --> 00:29:56.570
If we applied this one,
if I could switch, if I apply the OU

576
00:29:56.570 --> 00:30:01.480
policy first, that sets screen saver
to 15, domain policy is second,

577
00:30:01.480 --> 00:30:05.240
and then that would be ten, so
this would change the outcome, right?

578
00:30:05.240 --> 00:30:08.798
So they order these policies are applied,
very, very important.

579
00:30:08.798 --> 00:30:13.060
And that, Daniel, I think is the basics
of group policy in a nutshell.

580
00:30:13.060 --> 00:30:17.450
>> Well Mikey, thank you so much for those
great explanations and demonstrations.

581
00:30:17.450 --> 00:30:20.180
Hopefully our viewers our
there are getting a good idea

582
00:30:20.180 --> 00:30:21.850
of what it means to work
with group policies.

583
00:30:21.850 --> 00:30:23.270
Not really that difficult.

584
00:30:23.270 --> 00:30:26.240
There's a lot that are in there,
all the settings and stuff so

585
00:30:26.240 --> 00:30:30.270
you can spend half a lifetime
going through each one of them but

586
00:30:30.270 --> 00:30:33.920
the basics of it, just linking a group
policy obviously creating a GPO,

587
00:30:33.920 --> 00:30:38.090
link it to where you need to, and then
making sure that order, that its being

588
00:30:38.090 --> 00:30:41.960
applied is in the correct one so that you
get the outcome that you're looking for.

589
00:30:41.960 --> 00:30:43.100
Thanks a lot again, Mike.

590
00:30:43.100 --> 00:30:44.780
You-
>> And like I said, like Daniel said,

591
00:30:44.780 --> 00:30:46.200
we've really just scratched the surface.

592
00:30:46.200 --> 00:30:47.440
That is the basics of it.

593
00:30:47.440 --> 00:30:49.460
There is a ton more we can learn,

594
00:30:49.460 --> 00:30:54.490
but for now, we understand that
the basic processing of those GPOs.

595
00:30:54.490 --> 00:30:55.310
>> That's right.

596
00:30:55.310 --> 00:30:56.130
All right, everyone.

597
00:30:56.130 --> 00:30:57.380
I hope you enjoyed this episode.

598
00:30:57.380 --> 00:30:59.420
We're gonna go go ahead and
call it a day thanks for

599
00:30:59.420 --> 00:31:02.173
watching I've been your host Daniel Lowrey
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

600
00:31:02.173 --> 00:31:04.315
>> And we'll see you next time.

601
