episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel describe the different common storage technologies in use in a Windows Server environment. They cover the advantages and disadvantages of each as they explain storage solutions like NAS, SAN, Fibre Channel, iSCSI, and NFS as well as some of the hardware requirements needed for them.
episodes.title: Storage Technologies
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.377 --> 00:00:16.176
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another exciting episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.176 --> 00:00:18.021
I'm your host, Daniel Lowry.

4
00:00:18.021 --> 00:00:20.861
Joining me today is none other than Mr.
Mike Roderick.

5
00:00:20.861 --> 00:00:22.310
How's it going today, Mike?

6
00:00:22.310 --> 00:00:25.680
>> It's another day in
paradise here at ITProTV.

7
00:00:25.680 --> 00:00:28.137
We're doing out MTA content,
our server fundamentals.

8
00:00:28.137 --> 00:00:31.929
And in this one, we're gonna be
looking at storage technologies,

9
00:00:31.929 --> 00:00:34.332
a very important part of our environment.

10
00:00:34.332 --> 00:00:35.658
We have lots of data,

11
00:00:35.658 --> 00:00:40.156
we have lots of information that we
need to make sure it's safe, sound,

12
00:00:40.156 --> 00:00:45.050
accessible, protected from unwanted
modifications, all that good stuff.

13
00:00:45.050 --> 00:00:46.280
But in this episode,

14
00:00:46.280 --> 00:00:49.910
we're really going to focus on
the technologies that we have available.

15
00:00:49.910 --> 00:00:52.670
There's several different
ones that we can choose from.

16
00:00:52.670 --> 00:00:56.150
Each one has advantages and
disadvantages, and

17
00:00:56.150 --> 00:01:01.040
most likely you'll end up using a
combination of these in your environment.

18
00:01:01.040 --> 00:01:04.720
>> That's right, in today's age you
need some of these high powered storage

19
00:01:04.720 --> 00:01:10.582
solutions to be able to adapt for things
like virtualization or large databases.

20
00:01:10.582 --> 00:01:13.940
You gotta remember, in a corporate
environment, there is tons and

21
00:01:13.940 --> 00:01:15.070
tons of data.

22
00:01:15.070 --> 00:01:20.402
I've worked in a corporate environment
myself where we've had 90s and

23
00:01:20.402 --> 00:01:25.226
100s of terabytes,
I don't know if 100s is a real word, but

24
00:01:25.226 --> 00:01:25.771
>> [LAUGH] Lots of [CROSSTALK]

25
00:01:25.771 --> 00:01:28.221
>> Lots of terabytes of data.

26
00:01:28.221 --> 00:01:29.020
>> Plethora.

27
00:01:29.020 --> 00:01:33.790
>> That's right, there you go, a myriad,
as it were, a cornucopia of data,

28
00:01:33.790 --> 00:01:36.260
there's gonna be a lot of it,
that's basically what we're talking about.

29
00:01:36.260 --> 00:01:40.240
And these storage solutions help us with
that, because they give us high speed and

30
00:01:40.240 --> 00:01:42.570
high volume, and
that's what we're looking for.

31
00:01:42.570 --> 00:01:44.820
And Mike, you're gonna show
us these cool technologies,

32
00:01:44.820 --> 00:01:48.900
how we can work with them, and again,
what's the disadvantages, advantages,

33
00:01:48.900 --> 00:01:50.160
pros and cons kind of thing, right?

34
00:01:50.160 --> 00:01:51.263
>> And that's the big for this exam.

35
00:01:51.263 --> 00:01:53.574
We're gonna take a look
at a couple of them.

36
00:01:53.574 --> 00:01:55.652
I'm even gonna show you how to set up one,
but

37
00:01:55.652 --> 00:01:59.490
I don't want you to dive too deep into
it as you're studying for this exam.

38
00:01:59.490 --> 00:02:03.950
Be familiar with the technologies that
are available, what the advantages are,

39
00:02:03.950 --> 00:02:05.050
what the disadvantages are.

40
00:02:05.050 --> 00:02:09.120
Because you're going to need to pick
the appropriate one for the solution for

41
00:02:09.120 --> 00:02:10.660
the problem that they
give you on the exam.

42
00:02:10.660 --> 00:02:14.830
They're not going to actually make
you configure host bus adaptors and

43
00:02:14.830 --> 00:02:16.750
fiber channels and all that good stuff.

44
00:02:16.750 --> 00:02:17.460
So let's talk about it.

45
00:02:17.460 --> 00:02:18.740
Let's start with local.

46
00:02:18.740 --> 00:02:22.250
Right, we know we've got to have local
storage and a few years ago I would have

47
00:02:22.250 --> 00:02:25.160
said you've got to have a local storage
to install your operating system on.

48
00:02:25.160 --> 00:02:27.630
That's really not the case anymore,
but that's another story.

49
00:02:27.630 --> 00:02:31.977
Our PCs that we sit at,
we've got local storage.

50
00:02:31.977 --> 00:02:36.531
Our servers that sit on our racks,
they typically have local storage, and

51
00:02:36.531 --> 00:02:41.085
what I mean by local storage is it's
physically attached to that machine,

52
00:02:41.085 --> 00:02:44.000
typically internally, inside that machine.

53
00:02:44.000 --> 00:02:47.050
You crack open your case,
you've got hard drives in there.

54
00:02:47.050 --> 00:02:51.320
They might be mechanical, solid state,
there's different technologies we can use,

55
00:02:51.320 --> 00:02:55.170
and If we go back,
if we travel back in time a little bit,

56
00:02:55.170 --> 00:03:01.340
IDE was a very common way to connect
these hard drives to our systems.

57
00:03:01.340 --> 00:03:04.131
Gosh, I don't even remember, Dan do you
remember off hand what IDE stands for?

58
00:03:04.131 --> 00:03:05.188
>> IDE?

59
00:03:05.188 --> 00:03:10.996
Oh, integrated [CROSSTALK] adapter, I
don't even remember, it's been that long.

60
00:03:10.996 --> 00:03:12.144
[LAUGH]
>> Right?

61
00:03:12.144 --> 00:03:14.370
And you don't have to worry about it,
just know IDE.

62
00:03:14.370 --> 00:03:17.760
And somebody out there in the chat room,
help me out, tell me what IDE stands for.

63
00:03:17.760 --> 00:03:21.916
But this is what we used to use,
used a parallel technology.

64
00:03:21.916 --> 00:03:26.874
If you remember those old ribbon cables
that you would see inside your machine,

65
00:03:26.874 --> 00:03:30.925
this is how you connect those
hard drives to your motherboard.

66
00:03:30.925 --> 00:03:33.430
You'd have, typically, two controllers.

67
00:03:33.430 --> 00:03:37.441
Each IDE channel could then have
two devices connected to it.

68
00:03:37.441 --> 00:03:40.889
So you could have a total of
four IDE devices in there.

69
00:03:40.889 --> 00:03:46.514
Your hard drive would typically take one,
if you had a DVD, CD-ROM drive in there,

70
00:03:46.514 --> 00:03:52.160
that would connect to one, but you could
add additionals, up to four, typically.

71
00:03:53.250 --> 00:03:57.882
Older technology, a little bit slower than
other technologies that we have today.

72
00:03:57.882 --> 00:04:02.818
Once we got past that IDE,
the next evolution was serial ATA.

73
00:04:02.818 --> 00:04:07.690
IDE you can also here call parallel ATA.

74
00:04:07.690 --> 00:04:12.290
Serial ATA was the next evolution and
it's almost like we went

75
00:04:12.290 --> 00:04:17.340
backwards to go forwards, because serial
is when we send one bit at a time.

76
00:04:17.340 --> 00:04:20.440
So, you can imagine like a train of bits,
right?

77
00:04:20.440 --> 00:04:22.430
One after the other, just streaming.

78
00:04:22.430 --> 00:04:26.550
We went to parallel, and
we all of a sudden had many more lanes.

79
00:04:26.550 --> 00:04:30.020
Instead of just one lane for
that data to go down, we had many lanes.

80
00:04:30.020 --> 00:04:31.900
And we could send eight bits at a time,

81
00:04:31.900 --> 00:04:34.990
if it was an eight bit bus or
whatever the case may be.

82
00:04:34.990 --> 00:04:36.880
Then we went back to serial.

83
00:04:36.880 --> 00:04:41.730
It actually becomes, once these computers
hit a certain speed and we were sending so

84
00:04:41.730 --> 00:04:46.470
much data down these that serial became a
little more efficient than parallel, a lot

85
00:04:46.470 --> 00:04:51.390
to do with the traces on the motherboard,
the distances, and the crosstalk.

86
00:04:51.390 --> 00:04:54.580
The interference we could
get between those wires and

87
00:04:54.580 --> 00:04:56.460
those parallel type connections.

88
00:04:56.460 --> 00:05:00.070
So serial ATA is really one of the most

89
00:05:00.070 --> 00:05:04.120
common ones we see nowadays in
most of your personal PCs, right?

90
00:05:04.120 --> 00:05:08.450
You crack your case open at home, and
you've probably got a serial connection or

91
00:05:08.450 --> 00:05:11.480
a serial ATA connection inside there.

92
00:05:11.480 --> 00:05:17.220
Another option would be SCSI,
small computer systems interface.

93
00:05:18.275 --> 00:05:20.180
SCSI is much more fun to say.

94
00:05:20.180 --> 00:05:24.210
This is not typically found
in your workstations, though.

95
00:05:24.210 --> 00:05:27.560
I don't know, David out there in the chat
room I think told me that some of

96
00:05:27.560 --> 00:05:29.680
the older IBMs actually
came with some scuzzy,

97
00:05:29.680 --> 00:05:34.990
some high end workstations might have
SCSI, because a little better performance

98
00:05:34.990 --> 00:05:38.790
out of those SCSI drives, a little bit
more difficult to configure, though.

99
00:05:38.790 --> 00:05:41.250
There's a little more to it
because you can only have so

100
00:05:41.250 --> 00:05:45.000
many SCSI devices on a bus and
each one has to have an identifier.

101
00:05:46.170 --> 00:05:49.270
Again, not something you typically
see inside a home machine unless

102
00:05:49.270 --> 00:05:53.020
it's a high end work station of some kind.

103
00:05:53.020 --> 00:05:58.130
Servers, it's almost always going
to be SCSI or serial, depending

104
00:05:58.130 --> 00:06:02.930
on the level of server that you have in
there as far as their internal drives.

105
00:06:02.930 --> 00:06:06.470
But that's all local search, and

106
00:06:06.470 --> 00:06:11.270
we need that, but, as we move
into that enterprise environment,

107
00:06:11.270 --> 00:06:16.170
we start finding a need for
centralized storage, for

108
00:06:16.170 --> 00:06:20.580
a way that I can have storage that's
accessible to more than one machine.

109
00:06:20.580 --> 00:06:23.550
Now with our local storage we
can share things out, right?

110
00:06:23.550 --> 00:06:28.310
I can create a folder and I can share it
out with a network, on a file server.

111
00:06:28.310 --> 00:06:29.940
I can create a shared folder.

112
00:06:29.940 --> 00:06:34.470
People can reach out and connect to
that share, and they can save files or

113
00:06:34.470 --> 00:06:35.860
whatever they need to do.

114
00:06:37.250 --> 00:06:42.920
But it's a little bit limited,
and the next evolution for

115
00:06:42.920 --> 00:06:48.730
centralized storage would be something
called NAS, or network attached storage.

116
00:06:48.730 --> 00:06:53.320
And I've got a drawing here somewhere if
I can find it, if we can pull that up

117
00:06:53.320 --> 00:06:57.078
on my screen, and this is an example
of network attached storage.

118
00:06:57.078 --> 00:07:00.120
Network attached storage,
that would be this green guy over here,

119
00:07:00.120 --> 00:07:05.272
is storage that's attached to the network,
crazy the way that works, right?

120
00:07:05.272 --> 00:07:06.520
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

121
00:07:06.520 --> 00:07:07.710
>> All right, but it is.

122
00:07:07.710 --> 00:07:11.250
It looks like any other
node on the network,

123
00:07:11.250 --> 00:07:17.150
like an example might be
a Buffalo TeraStation or a Drobo.

124
00:07:17.150 --> 00:07:20.920
Several different brands of never detached
storage out there that you can find.

125
00:07:20.920 --> 00:07:25.158
You can get an enclosure and
you slap drives inside that enclosure and

126
00:07:25.158 --> 00:07:29.060
then that enclosure has
a network adaptor built into it.

127
00:07:29.060 --> 00:07:30.410
You plug it into your network,

128
00:07:30.410 --> 00:07:34.520
they typically have a web interface that
we can use to configure them, and then

129
00:07:34.520 --> 00:07:39.490
anybody else on the network can go across
the network and connect to that storage.

130
00:07:41.760 --> 00:07:45.920
For a home, this is what I use,
like this is to share media amongst all

131
00:07:45.920 --> 00:07:51.120
the different devices in my home network,
in a SOHO network attached

132
00:07:51.120 --> 00:07:57.020
storage is a relatively inexpensive
solution for shared storage.

133
00:07:57.020 --> 00:07:59.980
There are some downsides to this though,
all right?

134
00:07:59.980 --> 00:08:01.861
And let me go back up
to the local storage.

135
00:08:01.861 --> 00:08:04.557
The serial ATA, the IDE, that SCSI,

136
00:08:04.557 --> 00:08:08.106
I didn't talk about some
of the down sides there.

137
00:08:08.106 --> 00:08:12.550
Biggest downside of that technology ,is
that it's attached to a single machine.

138
00:08:12.550 --> 00:08:15.770
And if that machine fails
I lose access to that.

139
00:08:15.770 --> 00:08:17.140
I've got that file server,

140
00:08:17.140 --> 00:08:19.870
everybody's dumping their stuff
up on that file server, or

141
00:08:19.870 --> 00:08:24.150
I've done folder redirection, so their
My Documents is up on that file server.

142
00:08:24.150 --> 00:08:28.500
That's great, until that file server's not
available, and now I can't connect to it.

143
00:08:28.500 --> 00:08:32.920
So my storage is tied to
that physical device, and

144
00:08:32.920 --> 00:08:35.580
if that device fails,
we lose all that storage.

145
00:08:35.580 --> 00:08:39.470
Where as never catch storage is not
attached directly to a machine.

146
00:08:39.470 --> 00:08:41.200
Right?
It's attached to the network itself.

147
00:08:41.200 --> 00:08:44.010
So now it's independent of my servers or
whatever.

148
00:08:44.010 --> 00:08:47.830
It exists on its own on the network.

149
00:08:47.830 --> 00:08:49.370
Downside of network cache stores,

150
00:08:49.370 --> 00:08:54.200
though, is access speeds,
is what it comes down to.

151
00:08:54.200 --> 00:08:57.920
In a home office, a small office
where you've got four or five,

152
00:08:57.920 --> 00:09:00.230
ten users, not too bad.

153
00:09:00.230 --> 00:09:01.310
But if you get 10, 20, 50,

154
00:09:01.310 --> 00:09:06.300
100 people trying to connect to that
network attached storage concurrently.

155
00:09:06.300 --> 00:09:08.750
You're going to see that thing just choke.

156
00:09:08.750 --> 00:09:12.510
It typically is not going to be
able to handle that type of access

157
00:09:12.510 --> 00:09:14.570
in the network itself
that it's attached to.

158
00:09:14.570 --> 00:09:17.680
It's attached to the same
network you guys are, so

159
00:09:17.680 --> 00:09:21.360
it's limited if you've got gigabit,
ethernet, 100 megabit ethernet or

160
00:09:21.360 --> 00:09:25.760
whatever the case may be It's
gonna be limited by that as well.

161
00:09:25.760 --> 00:09:28.640
And TCP/IP has some overhead
involved with, all right.

162
00:09:28.640 --> 00:09:31.740
It does error checking,
correction, and things like this.

163
00:09:31.740 --> 00:09:36.400
And all of that goes and
slows down my access to the data.

164
00:09:36.400 --> 00:09:38.130
Now we had a network-attached
storage here for

165
00:09:38.130 --> 00:09:41.430
a while,
that we used to host some of our images.

166
00:09:41.430 --> 00:09:45.050
And if you're imaging one computer great,
man, speeds were fantastic.

167
00:09:45.050 --> 00:09:49.150
If you're imaging two computers at a time,
didn't really notice too much difference.

168
00:09:49.150 --> 00:09:50.810
By the time I would get to that sixth one,

169
00:09:50.810 --> 00:09:54.160
I'd go down the row and
I'd say I'd start the imaging on this one,

170
00:09:54.160 --> 00:09:57.580
start the imaging on the next one by
the time I got to the fourth or fifth one.

171
00:09:58.690 --> 00:10:00.780
It took me forever just to connect to it,

172
00:10:00.780 --> 00:10:03.230
to see the list of images
I could pick from.

173
00:10:03.230 --> 00:10:06.330
Because it was already serving up
images to five other machines.

174
00:10:06.330 --> 00:10:06.980
Right.

175
00:10:06.980 --> 00:10:09.690
It's just not designed for that.

176
00:10:09.690 --> 00:10:13.640
So, it's typically something
you're going to see in Soho's or

177
00:10:13.640 --> 00:10:15.550

oh they're indestructible.

682
00:35:24.055 --> 00:35:27.870
Yeah, until you scratch it,
then it's pretty much useless, right.

683
00:35:27.870 --> 00:35:29.053
So that's the thing to think about.

684
00:35:29.053 --> 00:35:33.290
I think in regards to this exam,
that's probably what they're referring to.

685
00:35:33.290 --> 00:35:37.500
It's really another storage
medium that we could use.

686
00:35:37.500 --> 00:35:41.020
The problem with doing, say, backups to
it, if your backup is small enough, sure.

687
00:35:41.020 --> 00:35:43.180
But what if your backup is 20 gigs.

688
00:35:43.180 --> 00:35:47.230
Now you got to swap DVDs out you know
when it finishes writing to one.

689
00:35:47.230 --> 00:35:50.980
When you got to restore you got to
have that entire stack of DVDs.

690
00:35:50.980 --> 00:35:52.750
I do not see it as being very efficient.

691
00:35:52.750 --> 00:35:54.110
Maybe in smaller environments.

692
00:35:54.110 --> 00:35:56.820
>> Yeah plus writing through
them takes a little bit of time

693
00:35:56.820 --> 00:35:58.610
especially if it is capacity.

694
00:35:58.610 --> 00:36:05.030
It's an option, but it's probably not
a modern option that we use anymore.

695
00:36:05.030 --> 00:36:07.490
And that's why they're
kind of phasing that out.

696
00:36:07.490 --> 00:36:11.630
But, to know it for the exam, that is
basically what we're talking about.

697
00:36:11.630 --> 00:36:13.130
It's a nice piece of media.

698
00:36:13.130 --> 00:36:14.430
It is removable.

699
00:36:14.430 --> 00:36:16.840
You take it wherever you need to go,
you slap it in the drive,

700
00:36:16.840 --> 00:36:20.020
it reads it using the laser,
and, bada bing, you've got data.

701
00:36:20.020 --> 00:36:21.200
Right?
>> That's it.

702
00:36:21.200 --> 00:36:23.350
I mean, well, this,
I don't even have a DVD on here.

703
00:36:23.350 --> 00:36:27.230
If I wanted to play something off of
that or install software from a DVD,

704
00:36:27.230 --> 00:36:30.543
I'd have to get an external DVD player and
plug it in via USB.

705
00:36:30.543 --> 00:36:33.970
Because, everything's getting us so
thin, that small form factor,

706
00:36:33.970 --> 00:36:37.400
that they can't even fit
the mechanisms in there anymore.

707
00:36:37.400 --> 00:36:37.990
>> All right, Mike.

708
00:36:37.990 --> 00:36:40.640
It looks like we've gotten through
all the objectives for this.

709
00:36:40.640 --> 00:36:41.670
Have we skipped anything?

710
00:36:41.670 --> 00:36:42.690
Did I miss anything?

711
00:36:42.690 --> 00:36:43.360
>> I don't think so.

712
00:36:43.360 --> 00:36:44.070
I think we're good to go.

713
00:36:44.070 --> 00:36:45.390
>> All right.
Sounds good.

714
00:36:45.390 --> 00:36:49.210
Hopefully you guys out there watching
at home have picked up a lot about

715
00:36:49.210 --> 00:36:52.780
how to work with storage in
a Windows server environment.

716
00:36:52.780 --> 00:36:54.050
And you'll be ready for

717
00:36:54.050 --> 00:36:57.410
that exam by the time you sit down and
take that test itself.

718
00:36:57.410 --> 00:36:59.580
All right Mikey.
Let's go ahead and call this a day.

719
00:36:59.580 --> 00:37:02.651
Signing off for
ITProTV I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

720
00:37:02.651 --> 00:37:03.400
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

721
00:37:03.400 --> 00:37:04.938
>> We'll see you next time.

722
00:37:04.938 --> 00:37:11.690
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike crack open an actual server to help you learn to identify some of the major hardware components found within. Some of the components they point out include the memory modules, hard disks, processor, cooling devices, power supplies, and even ports for expansion.
episodes.title: Server Components
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.783 --> 00:00:17.030
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another exciting episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:17.030 --> 00:00:18.320
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

4
00:00:18.320 --> 00:00:21.490
Joining my today in the studio is Mr.
Mike Roderick and Mike,

5
00:00:21.490 --> 00:00:23.420
you've got something really cool
lined up for us today, don't you?

6
00:00:23.420 --> 00:00:23.970
>> I do.

7
00:00:23.970 --> 00:00:26.980
It is show and tell day here at ITProTV.

8
00:00:26.980 --> 00:00:28.640
It was always my favorite day in school.

9
00:00:28.640 --> 00:00:30.090
You can bring something in.

10
00:00:30.090 --> 00:00:33.260
You can show all your friends what kind
of cool stuff you have, well that's what

11
00:00:33.260 --> 00:00:36.410
we're gonna do here today, is I've got
a server sitting in front of me and

12
00:00:36.410 --> 00:00:38.980
we're gonna take a look at some
of the different components.

13
00:00:38.980 --> 00:00:40.810
On the MTA exam objectives,

14
00:00:40.810 --> 00:00:45.900
they're gonna call out identify
major server hardware components.

15
00:00:45.900 --> 00:00:49.150
So we need to be able to recognize what
these different pieces are in here.

16
00:00:49.150 --> 00:00:52.370
Now you're gonna find that if you've
ever cracked open a PC, your own PC,

17
00:00:52.370 --> 00:00:56.210
your home PC, or anything like that,
it's pretty similar to that.

18
00:00:56.210 --> 00:00:57.890
There might be a few extra pieces here.

19
00:00:57.890 --> 00:01:01.230
A lot more redundancy when
it comes to these servers.

20
00:01:01.230 --> 00:01:03.830
But the components are very similar.

21
00:01:03.830 --> 00:01:06.810
One of the biggest things
we'll see is form factor.

22
00:01:06.810 --> 00:01:09.880
That's a big difference
with these servers.

23
00:01:09.880 --> 00:01:12.450
Now servers come in a few
different form factors.

24
00:01:12.450 --> 00:01:15.310
You do have a tower form factor, and

25
00:01:15.310 --> 00:01:19.560
it's gonna look much like your
tower that sits next to your desk.

26
00:01:19.560 --> 00:01:23.180
Although it's gonna be a lot
deeper than your tower is,

27
00:01:23.180 --> 00:01:26.160
and a lot heavier, typically.

28
00:01:26.160 --> 00:01:29.030
But that's usually for
what we call SOHO environments or

29
00:01:29.030 --> 00:01:34.260
small homes, small home office type
scenarios, where you don't have a rack.

30
00:01:34.260 --> 00:01:35.780
You don't have a place to
put all these servers.

31
00:01:35.780 --> 00:01:39.020
In fact, you probably only have
that one server and that's fine.

32
00:01:39.020 --> 00:01:43.850
We also have something known as blade
servers and these are high end,

33
00:01:43.850 --> 00:01:46.730
you find these in large environments.

34
00:01:46.730 --> 00:01:51.360
Where it's just an enclosure,
and each server looks a lot like

35
00:01:51.360 --> 00:01:54.510
the motherboard you would
find in your machine at home.

36
00:01:54.510 --> 00:01:57.810
And when you need a new server,
you just buy a new blade and

37
00:01:57.810 --> 00:01:59.970
you slide it into this enclosure.

38
00:01:59.970 --> 00:02:02.870
And all the common connecting components,
the drives,

39
00:02:02.870 --> 00:02:07.730
the networking, is on what's called a back
plane, and you're just sliding a new board

40
00:02:07.730 --> 00:02:10.430
with a processor and
things like that, into there.

41
00:02:10.430 --> 00:02:12.850
So you're adding multiple
servers with these blades.

42
00:02:12.850 --> 00:02:16.320
But the one I've got in front of me here
is what we call a rack mount server, and

43
00:02:16.320 --> 00:02:17.320
this is probably,

44
00:02:17.320 --> 00:02:22.170
what you'll see more often than not
in most corporate environments.

45
00:02:22.170 --> 00:02:26.550
It's designed to go in one of those racks,
those floor standing racks.

46
00:02:26.550 --> 00:02:28.920
They can be half height,
they can be whole height.

47
00:02:28.920 --> 00:02:31.850
These guys slide in real easy.

48
00:02:31.850 --> 00:02:32.990
And if we take a look at this thing,

49
00:02:32.990 --> 00:02:35.860
you'll see that I've taken
the cover off and it's pretty long.

50
00:02:35.860 --> 00:02:40.225
As I slide it back and forth,
I'm gonna guess, somewhere around,

51
00:02:40.225 --> 00:02:42.075
two, little over two feet.

52
00:02:42.075 --> 00:02:45.077
I don't want to go too far to where I
dump this thing right off of the edge of

53
00:02:45.077 --> 00:02:45.580
the table.

54
00:02:45.580 --> 00:02:46.590
>> They are a little heavy.

55
00:02:46.590 --> 00:02:47.623
>> Yeah.
>> [LAUGH]

56
00:02:47.623 --> 00:02:49.885
>> So you can see I can't even slide it

57
00:02:49.885 --> 00:02:51.770
all the way in view.

58
00:02:51.770 --> 00:02:52.460
But that's a rack mount.

59
00:02:52.460 --> 00:02:56.970
So we can design to slide into those
racks you see, in the server closet.

60
00:02:56.970 --> 00:02:59.770
This guy's only a few inches tall,
maybe three at the most,

61
00:02:59.770 --> 00:03:01.860
something like that, all right?

62
00:03:01.860 --> 00:03:07.150
Once we crack the case open on this,
though, we'll find that the hardware is

63
00:03:07.150 --> 00:03:11.520
pretty easily recognizable,
if you've ever cracked a PC open before.

64
00:03:11.520 --> 00:03:12.930
If not, let's take a look.

65
00:03:12.930 --> 00:03:16.010
Let's dive in here and see what we've got.

66
00:03:16.010 --> 00:03:18.690
A couple things that we need
to be able to recognize.

67
00:03:18.690 --> 00:03:20.830
First would be memory, right?

68
00:03:20.830 --> 00:03:24.700
Now on this server as I slide
this guy up just a wee bit,

69
00:03:24.700 --> 00:03:29.670
underneath this little cover here,
I'm gonna find my memory.

70
00:03:29.670 --> 00:03:35.090
So there's my sticks of RAM just
like you would see in a home PC,

71
00:03:35.090 --> 00:03:38.150
although, you'll notice there's
quite a few slots in here.

72
00:03:38.150 --> 00:03:38.790
And then, of course,

73
00:03:38.790 --> 00:03:42.580
depending on the server,
is gonna depend on how much it supports.

74
00:03:42.580 --> 00:03:46.050
On this one, we've actually got
expansion slots off to the side.

75
00:03:46.050 --> 00:03:49.490
Or you can see the top of
a stick of RAM over here, and

76
00:03:49.490 --> 00:03:52.921
I can put more RAM over there, all right?

77
00:03:52.921 --> 00:03:58.466
It's got a lot of memory of
the capabilities to hold a lot of memory,

78
00:03:58.466 --> 00:03:59.460
disk wise.

79
00:03:59.460 --> 00:04:00.610
Well, let's stay inside here.

80
00:04:00.610 --> 00:04:05.830
Let's do, so we got our RAM, other things
we need to be able to recognize CPUs.

81
00:04:05.830 --> 00:04:07.730
I'll slide this guy back just a wee bit.

82
00:04:07.730 --> 00:04:11.270
You're not going to be able to see
the CPUs because they're residing

83
00:04:11.270 --> 00:04:13.200
underneath these heat sinks.

84
00:04:13.200 --> 00:04:17.620
These are my big heat sinks that
are probably, I don't know, an inch and

85
00:04:17.620 --> 00:04:20.130
a half by five inches or so.

86
00:04:20.130 --> 00:04:21.340
There's two of them.

87
00:04:21.340 --> 00:04:24.420
Because I have two processors
in the server, one for

88
00:04:24.420 --> 00:04:27.020
each one to keep those processors cool.

89
00:04:27.020 --> 00:04:28.950
If I can get Jason to
pull up my screen here,

90
00:04:28.950 --> 00:04:31.850
I've got a picture that I took of
this server just a minute ago.

91
00:04:31.850 --> 00:04:37.060
So from the side, you can kinda
see underneath these heat sinks,

92
00:04:37.060 --> 00:04:41.025
is where my processors
are going to reside, all right.

93
00:04:41.025 --> 00:04:42.660
They're gonna look like
any other processor,

94
00:04:42.660 --> 00:04:44.670
nothing too fancy to look at there.

95
00:04:44.670 --> 00:04:46.270
But again, there's two of them, right.

96
00:04:46.270 --> 00:04:50.900
Which you might not see that often on
a home PC, because this is a server

97
00:04:50.900 --> 00:04:54.890
designed to support connections from
multiple users simultaneously, and

98
00:04:54.890 --> 00:04:58.270
providing services to the network,
we need that extra power.

99
00:04:58.270 --> 00:05:00.520
So we've got our memory,
we've got our CPU.

100
00:05:00.520 --> 00:05:04.540
And then while we're in here,
we'll flip back over to that sky cam.

101
00:05:04.540 --> 00:05:08.010
We can see some of the cooling
involved in here, all right?

102
00:05:08.010 --> 00:05:11.920
So right in front of each one of
these heat sinks, are some fans.

103
00:05:11.920 --> 00:05:13.170
And these fans,

104
00:05:13.170 --> 00:05:17.090
there's actually four of them,
if I can get this little latch to open up.

105
00:05:19.170 --> 00:05:20.990
One of these guys will pop out for
me, there we go.

106
00:05:20.990 --> 00:05:24.670
You can see these
are actually smaller fans.

107
00:05:24.670 --> 00:05:29.790
But there are four of them, two sitting
in front of each one of those processors.

108
00:05:29.790 --> 00:05:34.380
Also notice, how easy it was for
me to pop that fan out and put it back in.

109
00:05:34.380 --> 00:05:38.630
These servers are designed
to be very modular,

110
00:05:38.630 --> 00:05:43.120
very easy to get in and
replace any component that has failed.

111
00:05:44.120 --> 00:05:48.950
There's also some more fans towards the
back of this server that help pull that

112
00:05:48.950 --> 00:05:51.440
hot air out then blow it
out the back of the case.

113
00:05:51.440 --> 00:05:56.000
So we've got our CPU, we've got our RAM,
we've got our cooling in here,

114
00:05:56.000 --> 00:05:58.310
what else do we need to look at there,
Daniel?

115
00:05:58.310 --> 00:06:00.560
>> Let's see here, well,
there's power supplies.

116
00:06:00.560 --> 00:06:01.070
>> Power supplies.

117
00:06:01.070 --> 00:06:03.650
You've got to have power to run this guy,
right?

118
00:06:03.650 --> 00:06:06.770
I don't think I can slide this up
far enough for you to see, but

119
00:06:06.770 --> 00:06:09.600
I do have a picture of
the back of this machine.

120
00:06:09.600 --> 00:06:14.740
And on the back here, you're gonna
see these two little handles and

121
00:06:14.740 --> 00:06:18.400
these are two separate power supplies.

122
00:06:18.400 --> 00:06:20.020
Again, redundancy.

123
00:06:20.020 --> 00:06:21.240
If one of those power supplies, and

124
00:06:21.240 --> 00:06:23.770
the server can run off just
one of those power supplies.

125
00:06:23.770 --> 00:06:28.740
If one of them fails, however, the other
one is still there, keeps on truckin',

126
00:06:28.740 --> 00:06:30.240
server's still up and running.

127
00:06:30.240 --> 00:06:31.790
And then watch how easy this is,

128
00:06:31.790 --> 00:06:34.608
if we flip back over to that sky cam for
a second.

129
00:06:34.608 --> 00:06:37.380
You're not gonna see this actual process,
but all I'm doing is lifting

130
00:06:37.380 --> 00:06:42.060
up that little black handle, and there's
the power supply that I just took out.

131
00:06:42.060 --> 00:06:45.170
There's that black handle,
we were just looking at the picture of.

132
00:06:45.170 --> 00:06:46.493
>> More modularity, right?

133
00:06:46.493 --> 00:06:50.398
Saying if that power supply goes bad, well
you've got the redundant power supply,

134
00:06:50.398 --> 00:06:52.060
the server's gonna keep rocking.

135
00:06:52.060 --> 00:06:53.880
You can go right into that server closet,

136
00:06:53.880 --> 00:06:58.040
snatch the power cable out of the back
of that thing, pull this guy out,

137
00:06:58.040 --> 00:07:01.430
do a warranty job, or maybe you've
got a hot spare sitting there.

138
00:07:01.430 --> 00:07:05.290
Slide it right back in, plug the cable
back in, and you're off to the races.

139
00:07:05.290 --> 00:07:09.802
This is what makes servers really up and
above the home PC.

140
00:07:09.802 --> 00:07:14.262
Even though you can use that type of PC
as a server because basically, servers

141
00:07:14.262 --> 00:07:19.203
are usually just a type of software giving
you a service, but for the redundancy, for

142
00:07:19.203 --> 00:07:23.490
that mission critical type of environment,
this is the way you wanna go.

143
00:07:23.490 --> 00:07:27.790
>> Absolutely, and he's exactly right, I
mean, I should have a few of these sitting

144
00:07:27.790 --> 00:07:32.310
in my closet somewhere, so that when that
power supply fails, I don't have to wait.

145
00:07:32.310 --> 00:07:35.810
Dell can ship me another one, but
I already got one in there and

146
00:07:35.810 --> 00:07:39.910
that new one that comes in just goes into
the closet, and becomes my new spare.

147
00:07:39.910 --> 00:07:41.970
So we'll pop that guy back in there.

148
00:07:41.970 --> 00:07:45.020
As we got our power supply again,
redundancy there.

149
00:07:45.020 --> 00:07:48.187
Another one we gotta deal with,
Daniel, is networking, right?

150
00:07:48.187 --> 00:07:52.762
Now you're not gonna see a big network
adapter, like you might on your home PC.

151
00:07:52.762 --> 00:07:55.955
In this, it's built in or
it's on the motherboard.

152
00:07:55.955 --> 00:07:57.734
A lot of our home PCs have that, as well.

153
00:07:57.734 --> 00:08:00.590
You have that integrated network
adapter on the motherboard.

154
00:08:00.590 --> 00:08:04.540
A lot of times we'll add an expansion
card if we want a faster one.

155
00:08:04.540 --> 00:08:06.330
This guy actually has two of them.

156
00:08:06.330 --> 00:08:08.204
And if we take a look at one of
these pictures again over here.

157
00:08:08.204 --> 00:08:11.230
If I can find it, there she is.

158
00:08:11.230 --> 00:08:12.370
There's the other side.

159
00:08:12.370 --> 00:08:14.740
This is still on the back of the server,

160
00:08:14.740 --> 00:08:18.290
you can see the edge of that power supply
over here to the left of that image.

161
00:08:18.290 --> 00:08:21.600
But then over here I can
see my network adapters.

162
00:08:21.600 --> 00:08:27.302
I got two gigabit network adapters
built in or integrated on this board.

163
00:08:27.302 --> 00:08:31.470
And again, redundancy,
I'm gonna have those cables.

164
00:08:31.470 --> 00:08:35.450
I'm gonna have this server hooked
up to two separate switches.

165
00:08:35.450 --> 00:08:38.270
So if one of those switches fails,
this guy's still communicating.

166
00:08:38.270 --> 00:08:41.240
He's still on the network,
people can still access resources.

167
00:08:41.240 --> 00:08:46.076
When both of them are up, we can do some
binding or some NIC Teaming where we

168
00:08:46.076 --> 00:08:50.683
start doubling up on our throughput but
the whole idea is redundancy.

169
00:08:50.683 --> 00:08:54.580
If one of those guys fails my
server is not out of commission.

170
00:08:54.580 --> 00:08:56.060
Everything is still working.

171
00:08:56.060 --> 00:08:58.440
I just have to get in there and
figure out how to fix that.

172
00:08:58.440 --> 00:09:02.380
Now, in this case, because it's integrated
fixing it's not gonna be so easy.

173
00:09:03.380 --> 00:09:05.510
So we could limp along until
we can figure that out.

174
00:09:05.510 --> 00:09:08.100
We might have to replace
the board at that point.

175
00:09:08.100 --> 00:09:10.600
That is the downside of
integrated components.

176
00:09:11.790 --> 00:09:15.080
But NICs like that typically don't fail.

177
00:09:15.080 --> 00:09:16.740
So hopefully we'll be okay there.

178
00:09:16.740 --> 00:09:20.090
>> And these are usually pretty safe
from environmental factors, lightning,

179
00:09:20.090 --> 00:09:21.990
power surges and things like that.

180
00:09:21.990 --> 00:09:25.990
Hopefully, you have something that
costs this much money on some sort of

181
00:09:25.990 --> 00:09:29.960
uninterruptible power supply with surge
protection, all that, spike protection.

182
00:09:29.960 --> 00:09:33.150
There's a lot of line conditioners and
things you can install, make sure that

183
00:09:33.150 --> 00:09:37.810
the power's always clean coming through
there and of course, on networking, you're

Understand what a processor is,
what memory is, what a hard drive is.

412
00:20:15.070 --> 00:20:18.290
You should have those
concepts down pat by now.

413
00:20:18.290 --> 00:20:19.850
If not, do a refresher.

414
00:20:19.850 --> 00:20:21.660
In fact, we can do a quick recap.

415
00:20:21.660 --> 00:20:24.860
Just to make sure everybody's familiar
with this cuz you might just be diving

416
00:20:24.860 --> 00:20:28.430
into the IT field, that is one
of the reasons this exam exists.

417
00:20:28.430 --> 00:20:32.180
The CPU that we talk about, that's the
brains of the computer, that's where all

418
00:20:32.180 --> 00:20:37.150
the calculations are occurring and
the RAM, the random access memory,

419
00:20:37.150 --> 00:20:42.370
that is where all of the data that's
being manipulated or worked with resides.

420
00:20:42.370 --> 00:20:45.560
Then you've got the hard drives,
that's our permanent storage.

421
00:20:45.560 --> 00:20:48.210
That's where we save things to,

422
00:20:48.210 --> 00:20:52.720
when we shut down everything goes to
the hard drive because RAM is volatile.

423
00:20:52.720 --> 00:20:55.270
The information that's
stored in RAM disappears

424
00:20:55.270 --> 00:20:56.930
when you power the machine down.

425
00:20:56.930 --> 00:21:00.220
So it all gets written to the hard
drive and then the machine shuts down.

426
00:21:00.220 --> 00:21:02.610
When that operating system
loads up again the next day and

427
00:21:02.610 --> 00:21:05.900
when you power that server up again,
everything gets written back to RAM,

428
00:21:05.900 --> 00:21:06.980
loads up the operating system,

429
00:21:06.980 --> 00:21:10.760
whatever applications you're running,
things like that get loaded in RAM.

430
00:21:10.760 --> 00:21:12.360
What else do we talk about?

431
00:21:12.360 --> 00:21:15.740
Network adapters,
connect us to the network right?

432
00:21:15.740 --> 00:21:21.530
What else, power supplies, take that AC
current that we're getting from the wall,

433
00:21:21.530 --> 00:21:25.470
convert it into DC or direct current
that we can use inside this server.

434
00:21:25.470 --> 00:21:26.520
>> Graphics.

435
00:21:26.520 --> 00:21:29.810
>> Graphics cards, right, that's what's
giving me that on screen display.

436
00:21:29.810 --> 00:21:33.590
Taking all those 1's and
0's that the computer's manipulating and

437
00:21:33.590 --> 00:21:37.000
turning it into something my little old
eyes can recognize, pretty pictures,

438
00:21:37.000 --> 00:21:38.140
wizards,
>> That's kind of helpful.

439
00:21:38.140 --> 00:21:42.040
>> You know it is, it's not the matrix, I
can't read those green numbers coming down

440
00:21:42.040 --> 00:21:44.530
there, so graphics are very important.

441
00:21:44.530 --> 00:21:45.510
Did I miss anything in there?

442
00:21:45.510 --> 00:21:49.450
>> Just some ports and power supplies,
I guess but you already covered that.

443
00:21:49.450 --> 00:21:50.890
>> Yeah ports you know.

444
00:21:50.890 --> 00:21:51.760
Expandability.

445
00:21:51.760 --> 00:21:55.340
The only other thing I do want to mention,
they call it out, it's a strange place but

446
00:21:55.340 --> 00:22:00.310
they do call it out in these objectives,
that's 32 bit versus 64 bit.

447
00:22:00.310 --> 00:22:03.260
And what they're referring to
there is the architecture,

448
00:22:03.260 --> 00:22:05.760
the platform architecture of the machine.

449
00:22:05.760 --> 00:22:10.050
We can either get 32 bit machines or
we can get 64 bit machines.

450
00:22:10.050 --> 00:22:12.908
What that means is, remember,
a bit is a one or a zero.

451
00:22:12.908 --> 00:22:18.280
A 32 bit system has a data bus
that's going into that processor

452
00:22:18.280 --> 00:22:19.740
that's 32 bits wide.

453
00:22:19.740 --> 00:22:24.360
You can think of it like a 32 lane
highway feeding data into that processor.

454
00:22:24.360 --> 00:22:27.580
So in that processor,
I can take 32 ones and

455
00:22:27.580 --> 00:22:31.650
zeros at one time, and
feed it to the processor.

456
00:22:31.650 --> 00:22:33.711
A 64 bit system doubles
up the number of lanes.

457
00:22:33.711 --> 00:22:38.230
Right, now I've got 64 lanes or 64 ones
and zeros being fed across that bus say,

458
00:22:38.230 --> 00:22:42.320
going into the processor and
going into the other components as well.

459
00:22:42.320 --> 00:22:43.420
Right.
So that's 64 bit.

460
00:22:43.420 --> 00:22:47.070
And there's a big advantage of
running 64 bit over 32 bit.

461
00:22:47.070 --> 00:22:50.510
In fact, the later versions
of server operating system

462
00:22:50.510 --> 00:22:54.190
are no longer available in 32 bit,
they're only gonna be 64 bit.

463
00:22:54.190 --> 00:22:57.870
2008 was right about that line where they
said, you know what, we're gonna stop

464
00:22:57.870 --> 00:23:02.100
making 32 bit operating systems for
server, we're going to only make 64 bit.

465
00:23:02.100 --> 00:23:05.490
Our client operating systems
are slowly going that way.

466
00:23:07.040 --> 00:23:09.570
For servers at this point, its all 64 bit.

467
00:23:09.570 --> 00:23:11.650
The reason is, the efficiency.

468
00:23:11.650 --> 00:23:15.800
So much more data can be traversed
across that BUS, into the processor.

469
00:23:15.800 --> 00:23:21.298
As well as another big key to 64 bit
is how much memory it can recognize.

470
00:23:21.298 --> 00:23:25.380
With a 32 bit system,
you're gonna be limited to 4 gigabytes.

471
00:23:26.455 --> 00:23:31.210
Cuz of the way the addressing scheme
works, and I tried to draw this up here.

472
00:23:31.210 --> 00:23:35.850
I've got a little drawing I did here on my
machine to see if we could visualize this.

473
00:23:35.850 --> 00:23:38.430
But basically, when you look at memory,

474
00:23:38.430 --> 00:23:43.980
every bit needs an address If I've
got four gigabytes of RAM.

475
00:23:43.980 --> 00:23:47.880
Then I've got four billion,
two hundred and some odd million, so

476
00:23:47.880 --> 00:23:51.390
many thousand bits of data that
I can store in there, right?

477
00:23:51.390 --> 00:23:56.080
All the way from zero,
that very first bit, to the very last bit,

478
00:23:56.080 --> 00:23:58.080
which is gonna be, this is its address.

479
00:23:58.080 --> 00:24:03.200
When the system wants to write data to
this spot or read data to that spot,

480
00:24:03.200 --> 00:24:08.010
or write data to it or read data from
it it has to call at its address.

481
00:24:08.010 --> 00:24:13.250
There's 32 ones right there
that would reference the very

482
00:24:13.250 --> 00:24:19.190
last spot in four gigs of RAM, all right,
what if I have more then four gigs of RAM,

483
00:24:19.190 --> 00:24:26.280
what if I want to address something
over here, well, let's do that again.

484
00:24:26.280 --> 00:24:30.480
It's not going to give me my
little tiny box there, but

485
00:24:30.480 --> 00:24:33.970
imagine I wanted to address
something way over here.

486
00:24:33.970 --> 00:24:37.150
Well, I'm going to need more ones.

487
00:24:37.150 --> 00:24:40.640
Right?
This is as far as I can go with 32 bits.

488
00:24:40.640 --> 00:24:43.320
I can't make a bigger number.

489
00:24:43.320 --> 00:24:47.100
So with 64 bits I double
the number of bits I had there.

490
00:24:47.100 --> 00:24:52.360
So now, I can address RAM way
beyond that four gigabyte barrier.

491
00:24:52.360 --> 00:24:56.680
All right, and we know in today's systems,
we need more then four gigabytes of RAM,

492
00:24:56.680 --> 00:25:00.870
even in your home systems, you have
at least two probably if not more,

493
00:25:00.870 --> 00:25:05.790
in these servers we're talking 64,
128 gigs of RAM that we want to use,

494
00:25:05.790 --> 00:25:10.110
we need that 64 bit operating system
to take advantage of all that memory.

495
00:25:10.110 --> 00:25:14.050
>> Well, and fortunately, most of the
server that you buy today are going to be

496
00:25:14.050 --> 00:25:18.480
a 64 bit architecture cuz heck, that's the
way we're going its cause like he said,

497
00:25:18.480 --> 00:25:21.530
we need that much ram especially
when it comes to virtualization.

498
00:25:21.530 --> 00:25:25.970
They need tons of RAM cuz you're
using one piece of physical hardware

499
00:25:25.970 --> 00:25:29.038
to support multiple
virtualized pieces of hardware.

500
00:25:29.038 --> 00:25:32.340
So they're gonna be allocating two gigs
for that server, two gigs for that server.

501
00:25:32.340 --> 00:25:34.470
You think it sounds, 64 sounds like a lot,

502
00:25:34.470 --> 00:25:39.320
until you work in a large environment and
you've got 15, 20, 30,

503
00:25:39.320 --> 00:25:42.770
50 servers all trying to share this
resources, they run out really quickly.

504
00:25:42.770 --> 00:25:46.960
So even though it sounds like a lot,
it just depends on where you're working.

505
00:25:46.960 --> 00:25:48.944
Mike we've covered a lot today.

506
00:25:48.944 --> 00:25:50.791
>> We did.
>> Hopefully, our viewers now,

507
00:25:50.791 --> 00:25:54.674
even though you might have been familiar
with what a processor is, what is memory,

508
00:25:54.674 --> 00:25:56.515
how do you find that inside of a server.

509
00:25:56.515 --> 00:25:58.385
Hopefully, that's where you're at now.

510
00:25:58.385 --> 00:26:02.795
You can, this is a dell server, you crack
open an HP server, you crack open whatever

511
00:26:02.795 --> 00:26:06.435
type of server, you're gonna be able
to go, oh, yes, just from looking.

512
00:26:06.435 --> 00:26:07.155
There's the fans,

513
00:26:07.155 --> 00:26:12.210
there's the power supplies, there's
the graphics, hard drives, you name it.

514
00:26:12.210 --> 00:26:13.300
You're a little easier.

515
00:26:13.300 --> 00:26:15.312
Well, Michael, thank you so
much for pointing these out for us,

516
00:26:15.312 --> 00:26:16.851
getting your [INAUDIBLE]
>> I love show and tell.

517
00:26:16.851 --> 00:26:19.970
>> That's right, getting the cool
server out and cracking the case open.

518
00:26:19.970 --> 00:26:22.070
But for this show,
we're gonna go ahead and call it a day.

519
00:26:22.070 --> 00:26:25.150
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowery.

520
00:26:25.150 --> 00:26:25.880
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel describe performance monitoring methodology and procedures to help you keep your server running optimally. Unfortunately, slow downs happen to servers, so we need to be able to find out why. Tools built into the Microsoft operating systems like, Perfmon, Resmon, and Task Manager help us track down these problems so we can ultimately implement a solution.
episodes.title: Performance Monitoring
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.687 --> 00:00:13.536
All right, greetings everyone.

3
00:00:13.536 --> 00:00:16.435
And welcome to another
great episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:16.435 --> 00:00:20.263
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, joining me
on the show today is my good friend and

5
00:00:20.263 --> 00:00:21.897
colleague, Mr. Mike Rodrick.

6
00:00:21.897 --> 00:00:22.910
How's it going today Mike?

7
00:00:22.910 --> 00:00:24.060
>> Oh, it's going great Daniel.

8
00:00:24.060 --> 00:00:28.580
I'm as always excited to be here because
we've got our MTA content coming your way.

9
00:00:28.580 --> 00:00:31.271
This is what we're looking at,
server fundamentals.

10
00:00:31.271 --> 00:00:35.785
And in this particular episode we're gonna
be looking at performance monitoring.

11
00:00:35.785 --> 00:00:38.625
A very important part of
our job as an IT person is

12
00:00:38.625 --> 00:00:43.169
gonna be to make sure those servers
are giving us the performance that we need

13
00:00:43.169 --> 00:00:47.710
to make sure everybody else can do
their job, make our company money.

14
00:00:47.710 --> 00:00:48.800
All that good stuff, right?

15
00:00:48.800 --> 00:00:51.241
Doesn't do any good to set
all these servers up and

16
00:00:51.241 --> 00:00:54.978
then if people have to wait to log on,
if they have to wait for DNS responses.

17
00:00:54.978 --> 00:00:58.300
So our job is to make sure that those
servers are performing adequately,

18
00:00:58.300 --> 00:00:59.940
giving us the performance we need.

19
00:00:59.940 --> 00:01:03.876
And if not, finding out about it and
doing something about it, right?

20
00:01:03.876 --> 00:01:04.981
>> Yeah, that's exactly right.

21
00:01:04.981 --> 00:01:08.795
So we're going to spend half of our time
fielding on wondering is this server

22
00:01:08.795 --> 00:01:09.880
running optimally?

23
00:01:09.880 --> 00:01:11.780
Is it handling the load necessary?

24
00:01:11.780 --> 00:01:12.566
Do I need to upgrade?

25
00:01:12.566 --> 00:01:13.550
Do I need to add more RAM?

26
00:01:13.550 --> 00:01:16.210
Do I need to add a new CPU to this thing?

27
00:01:16.210 --> 00:01:16.872
Who knows.

28
00:01:16.872 --> 00:01:20.630
Well we're going to use some tools today
to take a look into that to find out if

29
00:01:20.630 --> 00:01:23.822
our servers are actually even doing
what it is we need them to do.

30
00:01:23.822 --> 00:01:26.573
Are they performing in a way
that is working for us?

31
00:01:26.573 --> 00:01:30.996
Mike's gonna show us some neat ways
to figure that kind of thing out, but

32
00:01:30.996 --> 00:01:35.130
first we need to figure out what
actually causes computers to work,

33
00:01:35.130 --> 00:01:39.358
to have to trudge along and maybe even
get slow on us from time to time.

34
00:01:39.358 --> 00:01:40.685
>> So we're gonna plug them into the wall,

35
00:01:40.685 --> 00:01:43.092
we're gonna give them a little
electricity, and they should work now.

36
00:01:43.092 --> 00:01:43.711
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

37
00:01:43.711 --> 00:01:45.640
>> Yeah, Daniel's absolutely right.

38
00:01:45.640 --> 00:01:50.260
When we set up our network, our networks
sorta are dynamic, things change, right?

39
00:01:50.260 --> 00:01:53.310
We hire more people, we add new services.

40
00:01:53.310 --> 00:01:56.090
So while those servers might have been
able to handle the workload we had

41
00:01:56.090 --> 00:01:57.920
them under initially.

42
00:01:57.920 --> 00:02:00.790
If we don't stay on top of it,
and monitor these changes, and

43
00:02:00.790 --> 00:02:04.370
see how these changes
are effecting our servers then, we

44
00:02:04.370 --> 00:02:07.860
could end up in a situation where all of
a sudden performance just hit the floor.

45
00:02:07.860 --> 00:02:11.520
We wanna try to figure that out well
before we get to that point, right?

46
00:02:11.520 --> 00:02:16.210
We wanna see that downward
slope in performance and

47
00:02:16.210 --> 00:02:19.690
do something about it before it gets
too bad, to where people on the network

48
00:02:19.690 --> 00:02:22.440
are noticing or applications are noticing,
things like that.

49
00:02:22.440 --> 00:02:26.452
So as Daniel said, the first thing we want
to talk about is just the effects and

50
00:02:26.452 --> 00:02:27.517
what you might see.

51
00:02:27.517 --> 00:02:30.850
And most of this, you've probably
seen it on your own machines.

52
00:02:30.850 --> 00:02:34.349
It's gonna be no different when we
look at a sever operating system.

53
00:02:34.349 --> 00:02:38.270
You've got the four main subsystems
that we typically monitor.

54
00:02:38.270 --> 00:02:42.300
That's gonna be CPU,
memory, disk and network.

55
00:02:42.300 --> 00:02:44.835
So those are the four main subsystems.

56
00:02:44.835 --> 00:02:47.945
And of course, there's lots of other
things that we can monitor, but

57
00:02:47.945 --> 00:02:49.009
those are the biggies.

58
00:02:49.009 --> 00:02:53.832
CPU, my Central Processing Unit,
the brains of my machine,

59
00:02:53.832 --> 00:02:58.395
if that guy is busy then everything
seems to come to a halt.

60
00:02:58.395 --> 00:03:02.223
If you've ever been on your machine and
it's just not responding and

61
00:03:02.223 --> 00:03:04.672
you click on things, nothings happening.

62
00:03:04.672 --> 00:03:09.094
If you can even get task manager to open
up, which is a tool we're gonna look at,

63
00:03:09.094 --> 00:03:12.394
you'll see that that CPU
utilization is through the roof.

64
00:03:12.394 --> 00:03:16.922
It's at 99 or 100%, and
if the CPU is at 100% utilization or

65
00:03:16.922 --> 00:03:21.708
99% utilization, your computer
really can't do anything, right?

66
00:03:21.708 --> 00:03:25.619
Everything has to talk to the,
just about everything, I should say,

67
00:03:25.619 --> 00:03:27.260
has to talk to that CPU.

68
00:03:27.260 --> 00:03:29.467
And they're all waiting in
line to talk to that CPU.

69
00:03:29.467 --> 00:03:33.233
And if he's too busy, the line just
keeps getting longer and longer, and

70
00:03:33.233 --> 00:03:34.580
nothing is getting done.

71
00:03:34.580 --> 00:03:38.220
And that's when you see that,
almost that total system lock up.

72
00:03:38.220 --> 00:03:39.537
>> Yeah, I quit it too.

73
00:03:39.537 --> 00:03:42.797
And if I were to try and
have you do advanced calculus,

74
00:03:42.797 --> 00:03:47.087
and read the collected works of
William Shakespeare at the same time.

75
00:03:47.087 --> 00:03:50.090
If I asked you something simple like,
what is your address?

76
00:03:50.090 --> 00:03:53.020
You would struggle to work that because
you've got so many things going on.

77
00:03:53.020 --> 00:03:55.620
Well a CPU, like Mike said,
is the brain of our computer.

78
00:03:55.620 --> 00:03:58.610
It's what does the thinking and
the calculations.

79
00:03:58.610 --> 00:04:02.110
If its too busy,
well even simple tasks like

80
00:04:02.110 --> 00:04:05.040
clicking the start button is
going to be a challenge for it.

81
00:04:05.040 --> 00:04:07.241
And that's when you start seeing
slow downs on the server.

82
00:04:07.241 --> 00:04:11.521
You've got to remember, servers at their
basics are just a computer like you have

83
00:04:11.521 --> 00:04:14.150
your laptop or
your desktop sitting at home.

84
00:04:14.150 --> 00:04:17.787
The only real difference is that they're
usually a little better, they're beefier.

85
00:04:17.787 --> 00:04:20.305
Because they need to be because
they handle a larger load.

86
00:04:20.305 --> 00:04:24.694
That doesn't mean we can't overwhelm them
and from time to time that does happen.

87
00:04:24.694 --> 00:04:28.055
[LAUGH] I've definitely seen some
servers crawl into a hole before.

88
00:04:28.055 --> 00:04:29.924
>> Mm-hm, absolutely.

89
00:04:29.924 --> 00:04:32.290
All right, so
CPU is a big one we gotta watch.

90
00:04:32.290 --> 00:04:34.710
The next one we wanna
talk about is memory.

91
00:04:34.710 --> 00:04:38.978
Memory is a little bit trickier,
typically, to recognize the signs or

92
00:04:38.978 --> 00:04:43.686
to figure out that it is actually memory
that's causing the system slowdown.

93
00:04:43.686 --> 00:04:46.839
And we have a certain amount of RAM
installed in these machines and

94
00:04:46.839 --> 00:04:47.535
our servers.

95
00:04:47.535 --> 00:04:50.292
And of course as we add more and
more services,

96
00:04:50.292 --> 00:04:53.983
some of those services can be
very memory dependent, right?

97
00:04:53.983 --> 00:04:55.584
It has to load everything up into memory,

98
00:04:55.584 --> 00:04:58.050
you guys remember your
basics of computers, right?

99
00:04:58.050 --> 00:05:01.849
Everything that's on the hard drive,
we can't work with data that's on the hard

100
00:05:01.849 --> 00:05:04.837
drive, it has to be loaded up into RAM so
that we can work with it.

101
00:05:04.837 --> 00:05:08.603
Some applications are more memory
intensive than others, like DNS for

102
00:05:08.603 --> 00:05:09.173
example.

103
00:05:09.173 --> 00:05:12.468
Has to load up all those
zones up into memory so

104
00:05:12.468 --> 00:05:15.085
that it can respond to DNS queries.

105
00:05:15.085 --> 00:05:17.481
And what happens when we
start running out of memory,

106
00:05:17.481 --> 00:05:19.360
well the computer doesn't lock up.

107
00:05:19.360 --> 00:05:22.390
It's not like the CPU where
everything just freezes up.

108
00:05:22.390 --> 00:05:26.280
When we run low on memory,
my system has a way of dealing with that,

00:29:20.590 --> 00:29:23.560
Down here at the bottom, there's
a little show description checkmark.

564
00:29:23.560 --> 00:29:27.539
And I can see oh, oh, percent one
time is the percentage of time for

565
00:29:27.539 --> 00:29:31.110
a processor spends in the C1
low power idle state, right?

566
00:29:31.110 --> 00:29:31.654
Who knew?

567
00:29:31.654 --> 00:29:33.394
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Someone did,

568
00:29:33.394 --> 00:29:34.625
they wrote the description.

569
00:29:34.625 --> 00:29:35.400
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, someone did.

570
00:29:35.400 --> 00:29:36.390
That is true.

571
00:29:36.390 --> 00:29:38.930
So we can use that as you're
going through these counters.

572
00:29:38.930 --> 00:29:41.720
If you're not sure what a counter is,
just check that little checkmark and

573
00:29:41.720 --> 00:29:43.080
it's going to tell you what it is.

574
00:29:43.080 --> 00:29:44.620
Now, it might not help you.

575
00:29:44.620 --> 00:29:46.980
You might read that and go, what?

576
00:29:46.980 --> 00:29:50.630
That's when a little more research
is gonna have to come in.

577
00:29:50.630 --> 00:29:52.995
Also knowing what the numbers mean.

578
00:29:52.995 --> 00:29:57.480
Like if you're monitoring, I don't know,

579
00:29:57.480 --> 00:30:00.660
a disk queue link on one
of your hard drives, and

580
00:30:00.660 --> 00:30:04.510
Performance Monitor's telling you it's
five to seven, somewhere around there.

581
00:30:04.510 --> 00:30:05.728
Is that good?

582
00:30:05.728 --> 00:30:08.250
Is that bad?

583
00:30:08.250 --> 00:30:09.830
It's another thing that
you've gotta learn over time.

584
00:30:09.830 --> 00:30:12.010
You've gotta learn your systems,
you've gotta monitor them,

585
00:30:12.010 --> 00:30:14.360
you gotta see what's normal for you.

586
00:30:14.360 --> 00:30:18.260
A little bit of research can help, but
it is one of those things that you really

587
00:30:18.260 --> 00:30:22.240
just have to learn, for
example, the disk queue length

588
00:30:22.240 --> 00:30:27.270
is how many things are waiting in line for
usage of the hard drive.

589
00:30:27.270 --> 00:30:31.220
And the longer that queue gets that means
the more things that are waiting in line.

590
00:30:31.220 --> 00:30:33.850
But it also has to do with
how many spindles you have.

591
00:30:33.850 --> 00:30:37.220
Well will effect whether
that number is good or bad.

592
00:30:37.220 --> 00:30:40.000
The rule of thumb with
that particular counter

593
00:30:40.000 --> 00:30:42.070
is the number of spindles plus two.

594
00:30:42.070 --> 00:30:44.900
So, If we got a single drive,
that's one spindle,

595
00:30:44.900 --> 00:30:49.090
plus two that makes my averages queue
length should be somewhere around three.

596
00:30:49.090 --> 00:30:51.428
It's not always going to be three,
it might go up a little bit,

597
00:30:51.428 --> 00:30:53.693
it might go down a little bit,
but on average, about three.

598
00:30:53.693 --> 00:30:56.287
If I've got a five-disk array, well,

599
00:30:56.287 --> 00:30:59.504
that's five spindles plus two,
that's seven.

600
00:30:59.504 --> 00:31:02.543
So my disk queue length should
be somewhere around seven,

601
00:31:02.543 --> 00:31:05.965
maybe balancing between five and
nine, or something like that.

602
00:31:05.965 --> 00:31:10.436
So again, the whole idea is that you're
gonna have to spend some time learning

603
00:31:10.436 --> 00:31:15.109
what these counters are, which ones you
need to monitor, and it just takes time,

604
00:31:15.109 --> 00:31:16.495
it takes experience.

605
00:31:16.495 --> 00:31:21.930
So another real time monitoring
tool we've got our task manager,

606
00:31:21.930 --> 00:31:24.010
we've got Resource Monitor and

607
00:31:24.010 --> 00:31:28.150
we've got the Performance Monitor
node of Performance Monitor.

608
00:31:28.150 --> 00:31:31.950
All three very good tools to use if you're
trying to figure out what's going on right

609
00:31:31.950 --> 00:31:34.800
now, what is it that's causing
the server to slow down?

610
00:31:34.800 --> 00:31:35.750
>> Yes, sir.

611
00:31:35.750 --> 00:31:38.660
And like Mike said, it's just gonna
take a little bit of experience.

612
00:31:38.660 --> 00:31:43.490
You need to spend some time realizing
how does this server normally work.

613
00:31:43.490 --> 00:31:45.100
And then you'll be able
to figure out whether or

614
00:31:45.100 --> 00:31:48.890
not it's actually acting slowing or
it's really speedy today, or whatever.

615
00:31:48.890 --> 00:31:52.340
That just takes experience with
that actual device itself.

616
00:31:52.340 --> 00:31:55.364
And you can use these tools to figure out,
oh, well now that I can,

617
00:31:55.364 --> 00:31:56.828
it's working the way I like it.

618
00:31:56.828 --> 00:31:59.975
I'm gonna go ahead and use these tools
to see how that looks graphically,

619
00:31:59.975 --> 00:32:01.490
you see all those metrics.

620
00:32:01.490 --> 00:32:05.770
Then, when things start going awry,
you can take a look at that,

621
00:32:05.770 --> 00:32:07.000
you see the differences.

622
00:32:07.000 --> 00:32:08.620
You'll know where the problem is.

623
00:32:08.620 --> 00:32:11.250
Mike, thanks so much today,
for those cool demonstrations.

624
00:32:11.250 --> 00:32:13.650
Great tools built into
the Windows operating system.

625
00:32:13.650 --> 00:32:15.510
Hopefully you guys got a lot out of it,
we sure did.

626
00:32:15.510 --> 00:32:17.910
We're gonna go ahead and
call it a day for this episode.

627
00:32:17.910 --> 00:32:21.070
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

628
00:32:21.070 --> 00:32:21.867
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

629
00:32:21.867 --> 00:32:22.943
>> And we'll see you next time.

630
00:32:22.943 --> 00:32:28.142
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explain how to take a system baseline to take a snapshot of normal system operation so that you can determine if and when a server is experiencing performance degradation. They will show you how to create and access the logs and alerts generated by the Perfmon utility, allowing you to compare data at different times under different loads on the server.
episodes.title: Logs and Alerts
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.872 --> 00:00:16.750
Greetings everyone and welcome to
another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.750 --> 00:00:18.010
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie.

4
00:00:18.010 --> 00:00:21.668
Joining me on the show today, well, it's
none other than our good friend, again,

5
00:00:21.668 --> 00:00:22.553
Mr. Mike Rodrick.

6
00:00:22.553 --> 00:00:23.570
How's it going today, Mike?

7
00:00:23.570 --> 00:00:25.660
>> Oh, it's another day in paradise,
Daniel.

8
00:00:25.660 --> 00:00:26.840
I'm excited to be here.

9
00:00:26.840 --> 00:00:29.970
We've got more of our MTA
content coming your way.

10
00:00:29.970 --> 00:00:32.200
In this one we're gonna be looking,
we're gonna continue, really,

11
00:00:32.200 --> 00:00:34.250
our look at performance monitoring.

12
00:00:34.250 --> 00:00:40.980
We're gonna be focusing more on baselines
or what we call baselines and alerts.

13
00:00:40.980 --> 00:00:45.100
There's a couple of things where we can
take monitoring up to that next step.

14
00:00:45.100 --> 00:00:49.150
We looked in previous episodes at doing
what we call real-time monitoring.

15
00:00:49.150 --> 00:00:49.760
And that's fine.

16
00:00:49.760 --> 00:00:55.073
When you've got a server that's got some
performance issues, users are calling

17
00:00:55.073 --> 00:00:59.776
you up or application guys are saying,
how come that SQL Server so slow?

18
00:00:59.776 --> 00:01:04.570
I need to go and take a look and see
what's going on on the server right now.

19
00:01:04.570 --> 00:01:06.400
Task manager, good choice.

20
00:01:06.400 --> 00:01:08.700
Resource monitor, great choice.

21
00:01:08.700 --> 00:01:13.930
Performance monitor adding the appropriate
counters, another great choice.

22
00:01:13.930 --> 00:01:16.960
But when we're talking about
monitoring for performance,

23
00:01:16.960 --> 00:01:21.490
we really need to, there's a little more,
I guess I should say, that we need to do

24
00:01:22.590 --> 00:01:27.180
to really reap the benefits of being
able to monitor service performance.

25
00:01:27.180 --> 00:01:30.370
And the big thing is,
what we call creating a baseline.

26
00:01:30.370 --> 00:01:33.880
Because when it comes down to it,
performance is relative.

27
00:01:33.880 --> 00:01:37.420
You cannot monitor a server for
a couple of minutes

28
00:01:37.420 --> 00:01:42.700
one random time throughout the day and go,
wow, that server's performing really well.

29
00:01:42.700 --> 00:01:46.460
Or you're right,
that server's performing really slow.

30
00:01:46.460 --> 00:01:47.080
Think about this.

31
00:01:47.080 --> 00:01:51.010
If I've got a laptop,
I could pass that laptop around to Daniel,

32
00:01:51.010 --> 00:01:53.990
to everybody else here at ITPro or
to you guys out there.

33
00:01:53.990 --> 00:01:57.250
Each one of you gets on that laptop,
does whatever it is, and

34
00:01:57.250 --> 00:02:01.380
some of you might come back to me and
say, yeah, that laptop, it's pretty fast.

35
00:02:01.380 --> 00:02:06.180
Because compared to your old 1992 laptop,
it's smoking fast.

36
00:02:06.180 --> 00:02:07.764
>> My Toshiba Satellite is awesome, Mike.

37
00:02:07.764 --> 00:02:08.566
>> [LAUGH] Right.

38
00:02:08.566 --> 00:02:10.490
>> [LAUGH]
>> But you take that same laptop, and

39
00:02:10.490 --> 00:02:14.680
you hand it to Nate, and Nate's used to
work on his super cray and he's gonna say,

40
00:02:14.680 --> 00:02:15.830
well, this laptop stinks.

41
00:02:15.830 --> 00:02:17.780
It's really darn slow.

42
00:02:17.780 --> 00:02:20.610
It's all about,
what do you have to compare it to?

43
00:02:20.610 --> 00:02:23.220
That's when I say performance
is very relative.

44
00:02:23.220 --> 00:02:26.910
You've gotta have something to compare it
to, to get an accurate representation.

45
00:02:26.910 --> 00:02:30.278
I can't come into your network,
look at one of your servers and go, yeah,

46
00:02:30.278 --> 00:02:32.047
that thing's performing really bad.

47
00:02:32.047 --> 00:02:33.729
I mean, there's a few obvious things.

48
00:02:33.729 --> 00:02:38.124
If the GPU is pegged, or the whole
system's unresponsive but in general,

49
00:02:38.124 --> 00:02:41.264
I can't tell you if that
server's performing good or

50
00:02:41.264 --> 00:02:44.502
bad because I don't know
what its normal workload is.

51
00:02:44.502 --> 00:02:47.070
I don't know how it's normally performing.

52
00:02:47.070 --> 00:02:49.070
So we need to create a baseline.

53
00:02:49.070 --> 00:02:52.920
And a baseline is simply capturing
performance information and

54
00:02:52.920 --> 00:02:57.940
saving it and doing it during a time when
the server's doing its normal thing.

55
00:02:57.940 --> 00:03:02.170
When it's under a normal workload and
it's behaving properly.

56
00:03:02.170 --> 00:03:04.310
We're gonna capture all that information.

57
00:03:04.310 --> 00:03:08.440
We're gonna save it, and then,
in the future, when somebody says, man,

58
00:03:08.440 --> 00:03:12.810
that server is running really slow, I can
go back and capture that same information

59
00:03:12.810 --> 00:03:17.410
again and compare it to what I
saved the first time I captured it.

60
00:03:17.410 --> 00:03:21.130
And I can say now,
with a little more authority or

61
00:03:21.130 --> 00:03:23.510
accuracy that, yeah, you know what?

62
00:03:23.510 --> 00:03:28.280
Adding those 50 new users has really had
a big impact on our domain controller.

63
00:03:28.280 --> 00:03:31.970
Or no, it doesn't seem like the domain
controller is running the way it always

64
00:03:31.970 --> 00:03:33.850
has by comparing these information.

65
00:03:33.850 --> 00:03:37.260
But without that baseline,
nothing to compare it to.

66
00:03:37.260 --> 00:03:40.865
So it's very important that we establish
these baselines early on in the server's

67
00:03:40.865 --> 00:03:42.522
lifetime so we can go back and do that.

68
00:03:42.522 --> 00:03:45.900
And maybe this becomes part of your
normal maintenance in a once a week,

69
00:03:45.900 --> 00:03:49.030
once a month,
you run performance capture information.

70
00:03:49.030 --> 00:03:52.170
And you start archiving this info for
future use.

71
00:03:52.170 --> 00:03:54.150
Really, just depends on
what you're trying to do.

72
00:03:55.320 --> 00:03:57.630
Second thing I'll say about a baseline is,

73
00:03:57.630 --> 00:04:01.260
you've got to make sure you're
capturing accurate information.

74
00:04:01.260 --> 00:04:05.740
And when I say accurate, I don't mean
that it could be bad info because you're

75
00:04:05.740 --> 00:04:09.300
letting the computer do it, you're adding
counters, it's capturing what's going on.

76
00:04:09.300 --> 00:04:13.730
But if my user, or my admin comes
to me Monday morning and says,

77
00:04:13.730 --> 00:04:17.850
you know what Mike, that DNS
server's just running really slow.

78
00:04:17.850 --> 00:04:19.950
Like, all right, all right,
all right, I'll take a look at it and

79
00:04:19.950 --> 00:04:21.290
we'll set it up.

80
00:04:21.290 --> 00:04:25.160
And then, later that afternoon I like to
stay late at work, as everybody leaves and

81
00:04:25.160 --> 00:04:26.410
it's nice and quiet.

82
00:04:26.410 --> 00:04:30.260
It's 7 o'clock in the evening and I go
monitor performance on that server and

83
00:04:30.260 --> 00:04:31.820
I capture the information.

84
00:04:31.820 --> 00:04:33.960
And the next day the boss comes in and
I show him, I was like,

85
00:04:33.960 --> 00:04:36.130
oh this CNS server is running really well.

86
00:04:36.130 --> 00:04:39.230
Well, I captured the information
at 7 'o clock at night

87
00:04:39.230 --> 00:04:41.030
when nobody else is on the network.

88
00:04:41.030 --> 00:04:43.380
The server is not under a normal workload.

89
00:04:43.380 --> 00:04:44.620
So that's not accurate.

90
00:04:44.620 --> 00:04:46.100
That's what I mean by accurate.

91
00:04:46.100 --> 00:04:49.055
You need to capture the information
under a normal workload.

92
00:04:49.055 --> 00:04:54.265
If you're talking about your domain
controllers, they experience a severe,

93
00:04:54.265 --> 00:04:55.195
I don't wanna say a hit,

94
00:04:55.195 --> 00:04:59.005
but they do a lot of their work like 8
o'clock when everybody's logging in.

95
00:04:59.005 --> 00:05:01.380
Those servers are gonna be really busy.

96
00:05:01.380 --> 00:05:04.880
Again it at, in the afternoon
when everybody is logging off.

97
00:05:04.880 --> 00:05:07.950
That file server, during those morning
hours, everybody is hitting it,

98
00:05:07.950 --> 00:05:09.950
trying to get their work done.

99
00:05:09.950 --> 00:05:11.920
So monitoring it in
the middle of the night,

100
00:05:11.920 --> 00:05:15.260
when nobody is using the network,
is not a good way to go.

101
00:05:15.260 --> 00:05:20.766
>> Yeah, like Mike said, this is a very
subjective topic, the idea of performance.

102
00:05:20.766 --> 00:05:22.140
Is this running fast?

103
00:05:22.140 --> 00:05:23.450
Is it running slow?

104
00:05:23.450 --> 00:05:27.290
Each server that you jump to, even
within your own environment, will vary.

105
00:05:27.290 --> 00:05:30.780
So we have to find out how
does it normally operate.

106
00:05:30.780 --> 00:05:34.770
And Mike those were great points about
don't wait until everyone's logging in

107
00:05:34.770 --> 00:05:37.520
this morning and
the server's under an extreme stress.

108
00:05:37.520 --> 00:05:42.180
Or don't wait until there's nobody doing
anything because those are gonna be skewed

109
00:05:42.180 --> 00:05:46.391
numbers, it's gonna skew your data, and
skewed data becomes skewed results.

110
00:05:46.391 --> 00:05:49.421
We wanna get the most
accurate result possible, so

111
00:05:49.421 --> 00:05:54.081
we need to figure out when is a good,
when has the network become homogenized.

112
00:05:54.081 --> 00:05:56.430
When has that equilibrium occurred.

113
00:05:56.430 --> 00:05:58.370
So we're trying to figure
out those best times, and

114
00:05:58.370 --> 00:06:03.788
that usually occurs between things
like lunch and login from the morning.

115
00:06:03.788 --> 00:06:06.830
So you try to find somewhere in there is
gonna give you a more accurate result, and

116
00:06:06.830 --> 00:06:10.640
therefore it gives you better
implementations when it comes to

117
00:06:10.640 --> 00:06:13.050
fixing things that
are actually running slowly.

118
00:06:13.050 --> 00:06:13.560
>> Yeah and

119
00:06:13.560 --> 00:06:16.920
there might be times that you wanna
capture some of that crunch time info.

120
00:06:16.920 --> 00:06:21.170
Because if my domain controllers are
running really well, say from 10 to 12,

121
00:06:21.170 --> 00:06:22.990
well, maybe there's not a lot going on.

122
00:06:22.990 --> 00:06:25.980
I need to know,
what's a good way to say this, Daniel?

123
00:06:25.980 --> 00:06:29.270
I do need to pay attention
to that busy time.

124
00:06:29.270 --> 00:06:33.061
Because I want my servers to be able to
handle that spike that they're gonna get,

125
00:06:33.061 --> 00:06:34.916
cuz I know it's coming every morning.

126
00:06:34.916 --> 00:06:38.271
So there are times when I do need
to capture that information and

127
00:06:38.271 --> 00:06:40.145
include that in my baseline.

128
00:06:40.145 --> 00:06:43.386
But what I really don't wanna do is
monitor this stuff at three in the morning

129
00:06:43.386 --> 00:06:46.187
when nobody's using it,
cuz that doesn't do me any good at all.

130
00:06:46.187 --> 00:06:49.057
You could have a server
with a crappy processor,

131
00:06:49.057 --> 00:06:53.048
a stick of RAM that's got a gig in there,
and one lonely hard drive.

132
00:06:53.048 --> 00:06:55.993
If nobody is actually reading and
writing to it, and blah, blah, blah,

133
00:06:55.993 --> 00:06:58.390
it's gonna look like it's
performing really well.

134
00:06:58.390 --> 00:07:02.262
>> Yeah, Mike, it looks like we really
need to categorize our results.

135
00:07:02.262 --> 00:07:05.610
I've got, under heavy load,
can I handle this.

136
00:07:05.610 --> 00:07:07.790
Under normal load,
what does this look like?

137
00:07:07.790 --> 00:07:10.440
Under light load, what are my numbers.

138
00:07:10.440 --> 00:07:13.813
Getting those different categories and
setting everything apart so you can take

139
00:07:13.813 --> 00:07:19.400
a look at the data is gonna really help
you optimize the system as best you can.

140
00:07:19.400 --> 00:07:20.496
>> Absolutely.

141
00:07:20.496 --> 00:07:22.737
So let's take a look at some of
the tools that we can use or

142
00:07:22.737 --> 00:07:24.740
the tool that we're gonna use to do this.

143
00:07:24.740 --> 00:07:27.350
And in a previous episode I
mentioned real time monitoring and

144
00:07:27.350 --> 00:07:29.090
I think I've mentioned it in here,
as well.

145
00:07:29.090 --> 00:07:34.910
Task manager, resource monitor and then
performance monitor has that one node.

146
00:07:34.910 --> 00:07:35.630
That's real time.

147
00:07:35.630 --> 00:07:39.170
In other words I add the counters,
I'm seeing whats going on right now.

148
00:07:39.170 --> 00:07:40.690
But if I wanna create a baseline,

149
00:07:40.690 --> 00:07:45.350
if I want something that I can refer back
to, I have to do historical monitoring.

150
00:07:45.350 --> 00:07:48.483
That means that somehow I've got to
capture the information and save it so

151
00:07:48.483 --> 00:07:50.262
we can go back and
look at it in the future.

152
00:07:50.262 --> 00:07:52.364
Now, let me show you how to do that.

153
00:07:52.364 --> 00:07:55.741
I'm simply gonna open up good
old Performance Monitor again.

154
00:07:55.741 --> 00:07:57.703
Same tool we saw before.

155
00:07:57.703 --> 00:08:02.503
And remember, we went to Performance
Monitor here and I was able to add those

156
00:08:02.503 --> 00:08:07.590
counters and I could see exactly what
was going on in the system right now.

157
00:08:07.590 --> 00:08:09.535

a couple of these terms that

Because the boot process has changed,

We're starting with, gosh dang,

38
00:02:13.150 --> 00:02:14.620

45
00:02:35.494 --> 00:02:37.380
>> [LAUGH]
>> It is just one of those things that

00:02:37.380 --> 00:02:39.230

47
00:02:39.230 --> 00:02:42.653
But yeah, the old CMOS, it takes over and

48
00:02:42.653 --> 00:02:45.670
>> It does,

49
00:02:45.670 --> 00:02:51.060
And our BIOS is that firmware that
basically gives us that low level or

50
00:02:51.060 --> 00:02:56.690
starts the system up and runs it through

51
00:02:56.690 --> 00:03:00.632
Now BIOS is the old way of doing things,

52
00:03:00.632 --> 00:03:05.891
UEFI is the newer version of the firmware

00:03:05.891 --> 00:03:10.160
really more towards 2012

00:03:10.160 --> 00:03:15.710
So for this exam 2008, we can primarily

55
00:03:15.710 --> 00:03:20.710
So, the CMOS loads up BIOS and
it runs POST, or that power-on self-test.

56
00:03:20.710 --> 00:03:25.241
And POST, again power-on self-test,
that's where it's loading up some,

57
00:03:25.241 --> 00:03:27.144
it's checking everything out.

58
00:03:27.144 --> 00:03:28.739
It's checking the hardware,

59
00:03:28.739 --> 00:03:33.590
it's making sure that everything is ready
to be handed over to the operating system.

60
00:03:33.590 --> 00:03:36.860
So, it's gonna verify things
like the CPU registers,

61
00:03:36.860 --> 00:03:42.750
the integrity of the BIOS code itself,

62
00:03:42.750 --> 00:03:46.994
The DMA, my direct memory access,

63
00:03:46.994 --> 00:03:51.672
It's gonna look at the memory and
see how much we have.

64
00:03:51.672 --> 00:03:58.050
It's gotta find it, see how much memory we
have available to use on this system and

65
00:03:58.050 --> 00:04:03.540
then it starts passing off control over to
other systems to continue that process.

66
00:04:03.540 --> 00:04:08.593
And we're probably familiar with this
if you've rebooted any machine, right?

67
00:04:08.593 --> 00:04:12.401
Any Windows machine since,

68
00:04:12.401 --> 00:04:13.426
You turn that thing on,

00:04:13.426 --> 00:04:16.310
you see all those characters

70
00:04:16.310 --> 00:04:19.073
This is before the operating
system loads up.

71
00:04:19.073 --> 00:04:22.366
And this is just BIOS pulling it off
of those firmware on your motherboard.

72
00:04:22.366 --> 00:04:27.220
It's going through all those tests and
at the end, you get that beep, right?

73
00:04:27.220 --> 00:04:32.360
That single beep code,
which means POST completed successfully.

74
00:04:32.360 --> 00:04:34.360
And then the boot process can move on.

75
00:04:34.360 --> 00:04:37.532

>> [LAUGH] Sounds like some kind of

79
00:04:41.720 --> 00:04:43.849
Well there's beep beep,
beep, beep, beep, beep.

>> [LAUGH] You don't want to

That's the worst one ever.

84

[LAUGH]
>> That's bad,

cover your children's ears
