00:04:53.595 --> 00:04:57.250
Cuz what it's telling you is, no.

87
00:04:57.250 --> 00:04:58.470
There are some other codes.

88
00:04:58.470 --> 00:05:02.135
They're gonna be specific to

89
00:05:02.135 --> 00:05:07.310
So you'd have to go look at their site to

90
00:05:07.310 --> 00:05:09.940
But they'll indicate things like hey,

91
00:05:09.940 --> 00:05:14.574
We're not gonna get too much further

92
00:05:14.574 --> 00:05:18.520
Or if it doesn't find memory or
anything like that.

93
00:05:18.520 --> 00:05:21.600
That's when you'll start getting
some of those POST code errors.

94
00:05:21.600 --> 00:05:25.580
But, normally we get a single beep
meaning all the hardware checked out and

95
00:05:25.580 --> 00:05:29.150
we can continue that boot process, right?

96
00:05:29.150 --> 00:05:33.170
Then what it's gonna do, BIOS is
gonna look for what's called the MBR,

97
00:05:33.170 --> 00:05:36.390
or the Master Boot Record.

98
00:05:36.390 --> 00:05:39.010
And this is typically, it's going to be,
I shouldn't say typically,

99
00:05:39.010 --> 00:05:44.170
it is going to be the first sector on
that hard drive, that very first spot.

100
00:05:44.170 --> 00:05:46.488
So as soon as it goes to
access the hard drive,

101
00:05:46.488 --> 00:05:50.032
that very first thing it sees is that MBR,
or the Master Boot Record.

102
00:05:50.032 --> 00:05:54.939
And in there that's where we're keeping
track of those partitions that exist on

103
00:05:54.939 --> 00:05:56.340
that hard drive.

104
00:05:56.340 --> 00:05:58.780
And you might have several
hard drives on that machine.

105
00:05:58.780 --> 00:06:00.533
And it'll look at all the different MBRs.

106
00:06:00.533 --> 00:06:03.748
And what it's looking for
is that active partition,

107
00:06:03.748 --> 00:06:05.898
the one that set to boot to, right?

108
00:06:05.898 --> 00:06:10.074
And that MBR is gonna
tell it where that is,

109
00:06:10.074 --> 00:06:16.686
it's gonna locate the boot sector and
then it's gonna hand control

110
00:06:16.686 --> 00:06:21.790
over to what's known as BOOTMGR,
or Boot Manager.

111
00:06:21.790 --> 00:06:24.290
The Windows Boot Manager, all right?

112
00:06:24.290 --> 00:06:29.380
This is where NT loader used to take over.

113
00:06:29.380 --> 00:06:32.940
You'd go through your POST,
BIOS would then tead out that MBR,

114
00:06:32.940 --> 00:06:36.380
hand over control to NT loader.

115
00:06:36.380 --> 00:06:39.930
Nowadays, it's gonna go over
the Windows Boot Manager.

116
00:06:39.930 --> 00:06:42.331
And this is a windows application, but

117
00:06:42.331 --> 00:06:45.696
it's independent from
the operating system itself.

118
00:06:45.696 --> 00:06:48.950
It's not part of the OS installation.

119
00:06:50.480 --> 00:06:55.060
Let's clear that up,
it is written when you install windows.

120
00:06:55.060 --> 00:06:58.424
But it's not part of the Windows operating
system that's being loaded up, right?

121
00:06:58.424 --> 00:07:01.500
You could have multiple
operating systems on that drive

122
00:07:01.500 --> 00:07:03.140
that we could choose to boot to.

123
00:07:03.140 --> 00:07:06.176
Boot Manager is independent
from those operating systems,

124
00:07:06.176 --> 00:07:07.669
it operates independently.

125
00:07:07.669 --> 00:07:13.228
And then what it's gonna do is
it's going to, with Boot Manager,

126
00:07:13.228 --> 00:07:17.512
it's gonna look for,
what's a good way to say it.

127
00:07:17.512 --> 00:07:20.095
It's gonna look for
that active partition, and

128
00:07:20.095 --> 00:07:23.564
it's gonna hand things over to
what we call Windows Boot Loader.

129
00:07:23.564 --> 00:07:29.101
It's winload.exe, and let me tell
you Boot Manager is bootmgr.exe.

130
00:07:29.101 --> 00:07:31.423
It's gonna the control
over to boot loader.

131
00:07:31.423 --> 00:07:34.996
Once it figures out what partition we are
booting into, what the operating system

132
00:07:34.996 --> 00:07:37.867
we're gonna load up is,
it's gonna hand it over to boot loader.

133
00:07:37.867 --> 00:07:42.827
Boot loader or that winload is
part of the operating system.

134
00:07:42.827 --> 00:07:46.584
So each partition that had
an operating system would have a copy,

135
00:07:46.584 --> 00:07:48.989
or it's own version of that boot loader.

136
00:07:48.989 --> 00:07:53.203
And boot loader is what's gonna load
the specific version of Windows.

137
00:07:53.203 --> 00:07:57.893
So again if we had that multi-boot
environment, and then it's gonna load up

138
00:07:57.893 --> 00:08:02.598
the system kernel and it's gonna begin
to boot the critical device drivers.

139
00:08:02.598 --> 00:08:06.932
So the stuff that we need to load up
that operating system, hard drives,

140
00:08:06.932 --> 00:08:11.695
network adapters, things like that,
it starts loading up all those drivers so

141
00:08:11.695 --> 00:08:15.988
that operating system can now begin
to start accessing that hardware.

142
00:08:15.988 --> 00:08:22.210
Now, if, what's a good way to say this,
we can do hibernation,

143
00:08:22.210 --> 00:08:26.940
we can shut these machines down, they can
go into that hibernation when we turn them

144
00:08:26.940 --> 00:08:30.290
back on or we wiggle the mouse
they come right back up.

145
00:08:30.290 --> 00:08:35.640
In that case before restarting this
system that's coming out of hibernation,

146
00:08:35.640 --> 00:08:38.570
boot manager, instead of handing
control over to winloader,

147
00:08:38.570 --> 00:08:42.460
is gonna hand control to winresume.exe.

148
00:08:42.460 --> 00:08:46.520
And when resume looks for
that hiberfil.sys,

149
00:08:46.520 --> 00:08:50.730
because instead of starting this
the operating system up from scratch,

150
00:08:50.730 --> 00:08:54.820
from the beginning,
we're now resuming a saved state.

151
00:08:54.820 --> 00:08:58.149
So all of that is stored
in that hyperfile.sys,

152
00:08:58.149 --> 00:09:02.410
and the winresume is gonna be
responsible for loading that up.

153
00:09:04.780 --> 00:09:09.580
So again,
basically post is gonna occur and

154
00:09:09.580 --> 00:09:14.990
then you're gonna have your, it's gonna
hand over control to the boot manager,

155
00:09:14.990 --> 00:09:16.470
it's gonna look for that active partition.

156
00:09:16.470 --> 00:09:20.520
It's then gonna hand that
control over to Bootloader, or

157
00:09:20.520 --> 00:09:24.200
sorry, Winloader which is gonna
load up that operating system.

158
00:09:24.200 --> 00:09:27.460
Low handover controls with
the Windows kernel itself, and

159
00:09:27.460 --> 00:09:29.160
then we get our operating system.

160
00:09:29.160 --> 00:09:34.030
So not a very complex process,
it's a few steps that are involved.

161
00:09:34.030 --> 00:09:38.070
As far as troubleshooting goes, it is
important that we understand these steps.

162
00:09:38.070 --> 00:09:41.590
As far as what we do if
something is going wrong?

163
00:09:41.590 --> 00:09:43.230
Well, there's not a lot.

164
00:09:43.230 --> 00:09:47.370
We can reinstall our operating system,
try to replace some of those system files.

165
00:09:47.370 --> 00:09:49.230
We can do a repair.

166
00:09:49.230 --> 00:09:50.860
Repair is probably your first and

167
00:09:50.860 --> 00:09:55.470
best option, because we can try to
repair some of those start-up files.

168
00:09:55.470 --> 00:09:58.030
Sometimes master boot record gets corrupt.

169
00:09:58.030 --> 00:10:00.040
We might have to go in and rebuild that.

170
00:10:02.110 --> 00:10:06.240
But that's about all I can really
think of there for that boot process.

171
00:10:06.240 --> 00:10:10.540
So in the exam objectives,
they're gonna call it things like BIOS, so

172
00:10:10.540 --> 00:10:14.280
be familiar with what that BIOS is,
basic input/output system.

173
00:10:14.280 --> 00:10:19.340
That's what begins that initial
boot process loaded up by CMOS.

174
00:10:19.340 --> 00:10:21.050
Understand what the boot sector is.

175
00:10:21.050 --> 00:10:27.700
The boot sector is that first
section that has that the MBR in it.

176
00:10:27.700 --> 00:10:32.160
The MBR is that master boot record where
all the information about the partitions,

177
00:10:32.160 --> 00:10:36.420
and specifically which ones are active or
bootable is located in there.

178
00:10:36.420 --> 00:10:41.900
You've got that Bootloader and
you've got boot manager and Winloader.

179
00:10:41.900 --> 00:10:44.550
They say Bootloader in the objectives.

180
00:10:44.550 --> 00:10:50.600
It's actually called Winload or Winloader
is what they're referring to there so

181
00:10:50.600 --> 00:10:53.160
make sure that we're familiar with that.

182
00:10:53.160 --> 00:10:55.320
So that Daniel is the boot
process in a nutshell.

183
00:10:55.320 --> 00:10:59.280
>> Yeah it really seems like what happens
is that the system is actually saying,

184
00:10:59.280 --> 00:11:04.320
okay I've got this one set of systems
that fires off this particular thing

185
00:11:04.320 --> 00:11:05.750
that gets the computer ready.

186
00:11:05.750 --> 00:11:10.840
So we have the, my goodness,
I'm starting off here, let me take a look.

187
00:11:10.840 --> 00:11:13.060
You fire off the computer and
post happens.

188
00:11:13.060 --> 00:11:15.990
It says, let me check the system,
make sure everything looks good,

189
00:11:15.990 --> 00:11:17.430
all the hardware is there.

190
00:11:17.430 --> 00:11:19.240
And like Mike said,
if anything goes wrong with the hardware,

191
00:11:19.240 --> 00:11:20.760
post is gonna help you out with that.

192
00:11:20.760 --> 00:11:24.800
Now we did come from a time where post
beep codes were very, very popular, but

00:11:24.800 --> 00:11:27.740
now a days they actually
use a lot of LEDs,

194
00:11:27.740 --> 00:11:32.340
like they light up certain numbers on the

00:11:32.340 --> 00:11:35.680
There's some light systems and
due to those light systems you can see,

196
00:11:35.680 --> 00:11:39.170
okay if this string of lights is lit
up then I know that this is my error.

197
00:11:39.170 --> 00:11:43.510
It's the same concept as the beep codes we
just don't get an audible tone maybe other

00:11:43.510 --> 00:11:47.980
than the success of that single beep
letting you know everything's good.

00:11:47.980 --> 00:11:51.990
But if you're missing a hard drive or a

00:11:51.990 --> 00:11:54.970
to show up, we wanna hear that

00:11:54.970 --> 00:11:57.850
that beep beep beep, or something,
whatever, you're gonna let me know.

00:11:57.850 --> 00:12:01.040
That, hey, I've got an issue here and
it's a hardware issue.

00:12:01.040 --> 00:12:05.270

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explain some of the common methods for maintaining business continuity like the necessity of taking backups in the case of data loss. They even show you how to setup backups using Microsoft's wbadmin utility built-in to the Windows Server operating system. Other concepts discussed are disaster recovery methods like offsite backups and cold/warm/hot sites. Also implementing Uninterruptible Power Supplies and redundancy methods like Active Directory Restore and Clustering.

into Active Directory and deleted an OU,

804
00:41:08.290 --> 00:41:11.600
and in that OU were
dozens of user accounts.

805
00:41:11.600 --> 00:41:13.850
Well now I've gotta
restore that information.

806
00:41:13.850 --> 00:41:17.600
So I go get my backup from
before the OU was deleted, and

807
00:41:17.600 --> 00:41:21.850
I restore it on that domain controller,
and I connect it to the network.

808
00:41:21.850 --> 00:41:23.980
Well, then you think,
okay, now that OU's back,

809
00:41:23.980 --> 00:41:26.660
he'll tell everybody else about it,
we'll be good to go.

810
00:41:26.660 --> 00:41:28.770
No, The problem is,

811
00:41:28.770 --> 00:41:32.210
the other domain controllers
are gonna say, hey, that was deleted.

812
00:41:32.210 --> 00:41:37.380
The time stamp I have for when that was
deleted is newer than the time stamp

813
00:41:37.380 --> 00:41:40.210
of when you created that OU, or

814
00:41:40.210 --> 00:41:43.080
from that back up,
cuz the back up was from last night.

815
00:41:43.080 --> 00:41:45.040
And so
they're going to actually delete it again.

816
00:41:45.040 --> 00:41:47.160
As soon as you get done restoring it and

817
00:41:47.160 --> 00:41:50.010
you plug it back into the network,
it's gonna disappear again.

818
00:41:50.010 --> 00:41:51.830
And that's not what you want.

819
00:41:51.830 --> 00:41:54.880
So we have to do what's called
an authoritative restore.

820
00:41:54.880 --> 00:41:57.500
And what we're doing is
we're marking that object,

821
00:41:57.500 --> 00:42:00.230
in this case that OU with
all those user accounts.

822
00:42:00.230 --> 00:42:03.350
And we're gonna change what's
called the update sequence number.

823
00:42:03.350 --> 00:42:07.230
And that's what they use to
compare versions to see who has

824
00:42:07.230 --> 00:42:10.100
the latest version of
an object when they replicate.

825
00:42:10.100 --> 00:42:12.738
And we're going to increase
that update sequence number,

826
00:42:12.738 --> 00:42:16.071
we're going to take the domain
controller offline, restore our backup.

827
00:42:16.071 --> 00:42:21.127
But before we put him back online we're
gonna use something called NTDSUtil

828
00:42:21.127 --> 00:42:26.354
to increase the update sequence number
on that OU and all those user accounts.

829
00:42:26.354 --> 00:42:27.282
And we're gonna increase it a lot.

830
00:42:27.282 --> 00:42:29.420
It's actually 100,000 per day.

831
00:42:29.420 --> 00:42:32.830
So if that backup is three days old,
it'll actually increase that USN,

832
00:42:32.830 --> 00:42:35.934
that update sequence number, by 300,000.

833
00:42:35.934 --> 00:42:41.180
That ensures that domain
controller's version of the object

834
00:42:41.180 --> 00:42:42.680
is newer than any other.

835
00:42:42.680 --> 00:42:47.000
To them it's gonna look newer than
any other copy that they might have.

836
00:42:47.000 --> 00:42:50.050
And they're gonna say instead
of deleting that object, wow,

837
00:42:50.050 --> 00:42:52.880
you've got the latest version
of that object, let us have it.

838
00:42:53.890 --> 00:42:57.470
So in authoritative restore you
bring domain controller offline,

839
00:42:57.470 --> 00:42:58.940
you restore your backup.

840
00:42:58.940 --> 00:43:02.680
But before you connect it to
the network you used NTDSUtil

841
00:43:02.680 --> 00:43:04.970
to mark that object as authoritative,

842
00:43:04.970 --> 00:43:08.910
increases the update sequence number,
then you bring them back online.

843
00:43:08.910 --> 00:43:12.430
When they replicate that deleted
object will get replicated it

844
00:43:12.430 --> 00:43:15.378
back out to all the other domain
controllers and everybody's happy.

845
00:43:15.378 --> 00:43:18.970
So just to understand the difference
there, you've got your normal restore

846
00:43:18.970 --> 00:43:21.670
which means let the other
domain controllers catch me up.

847
00:43:21.670 --> 00:43:24.380
That's also known as

848
00:43:24.380 --> 00:43:27.550
Then you've got the authoritative restore
where I need to mark an object as

849
00:43:27.550 --> 00:43:31.320

remains and doesn't get removed again.
